Title: The patient must 'let himself go' in what he says, including whatever comes into his head even if he thinks it unimportant, irrelevant, nonsensical, or embarrassing; he must not omit any thought because relating it would be distressing.
Work: FREUD'S PSYCHO-ANALYTIC PROCEDURE
Year: 1904
Domain: FREE_ASSOCIATION

Text Evidence:
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Work: FREUD'S PSYCHO-ANALYTIC PROCEDURE
Year: 1904
Domain: REPRESSION

Title: Brevity is the body and soul of jokes; a joke says what it has to say not always in few words, but in too few words - words insufficient by strict logic or common modes of thought and speech, even saying what it has to say by not saying it.
Work: JOKES AND THEIR RELATION TO THE UNCONSCIOUS
Year: 1905
Domain: JOKES

Text Evidence:
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Brevity is the body and soul of jokes; a joke says what it has to say not always in few words, but in too few words - words insufficient by strict logic or common modes of thought and speech, even saying what it has to say by not saying it.

POSITION 2,760 of 6,391
================================================================================

ID: JKS-0433
Collection: PRIMARY
Title: Understanding a joke requires recognizing its technique; the hearer must perform an unconscious operation opposite to the joke-work, reconstructing what was condensed or displaced, thus re-experiencing the economy that produced pleasure in the joke-maker.
Work: JOKES AND THEIR RELATION TO THE UNCONSCIOUS
Year: 1905
Domain: JOKES

Text Evidence:
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Understanding a joke requires recognizing its technique; the hearer must perform an unconscious operation opposite to the joke-work, reconstructing what was condensed or displaced, thus re-experiencing the economy that produced pleasure in the joke-maker.

When patients' delusional compulsion is loosened by revealing the repressed material lying behind it, they themselves bring forward solutions to the final and most important riddles of their condition through sudden ideas that occur to them.

This is why we find the same mistaken beliefs in every child whose sexual life is accessible to us.

Hysterical patients suffer from reminiscences. Their symptoms are residues and mnemic symbols of particular traumatic experiences.

ID: N/A
Collection: PRIMARY
Title: Every single hysteric and neurotic remembers painful experiences of the remote past and still clings to them emotionally, unable to get free of the past. Work: FIVE LECTURES ON PSYCHO-ANALYSIS
Year: N/A
Domain: N/A

Text Evidence:
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
The sexual instinct in neurotics has not advanced to final normal shape but remained arrested at or returned to earlier phase. Clinical types of neurosis (hysteria, obsessional neurosis) correspond to fixation at particular stages of libidinal development.

If someone's need for love is not entirely satisfied by reality, he must direct his libidinal anticipatory ideas to every new person who appears, and it is highly probable that both portions of his libido (conscious and unconscious) participate in this attitude.

Text Evidence:

In obsessional neurosis, there has been a regression from the genital stage to the earlier sadistic-anal stage, transforming loving impulses into hostile ones and sexual aims into destructive ones.

Text Evidence:
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Jung's modifications dissolve the findings of psycho-analysis by reinterpreting the Oedipus complex symbolically rather than literally, thereby making it a mere figure of speech rather than an actual childhood experience

Title: Hysterical symptoms result from the conversion of psychical excitation into soma...
Work: INTRODUCTORY LECTURES ON PSYCHO-ANALYSIS, LECTURE XXIV
Year: N/A
Domain: N/A

Text Evidence:
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Hysterical symptoms result from the conversion of psychical excitation into somatic innervation, with the symptom expressing a repressed sexual phantasy through a bodily manifestation

================================================================================

ID: N/A
Collection: PRIMARY
Title: Obsessional neurosis differs from hysteria in employing different defense mechan...
Work: INTRODUCTORY LECTURES ON PSYCHO-ANALYSIS, LECTURE XVI-XVII
Year: N/A
Domain: N/A

Text Evidence:
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Obsessional neurosis differs from hysteria in employing different defense mechanisms: instead of conversion, it uses displacement, reaction-formation, isolation, and undoing to manage repressed impulses

In obsessional neurosis, regression typically goes back to the sadistic-anal stage, producing characteristic ambivalence, omnipotence of thoughts, and ritualistic behaviors

Text Evidence:

Guilt (unconscious sense of guilt) arises from conflict between ego and superego, particularly when forbidden oedipal wishes persist in the unconscious, and this guilt can manifest as need for punishment leading to self-sabotage

Text Evidence:
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Resistance arises from the ego's need to maintain repressions and avoid the unpleasure that would result from becoming conscious of repressed material; this resistance must be systematically overcome in analysis

Domain: N/A

Text Evidence:
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
The fundamental rule of psycho-analysis requires the patient to say everything that comes to mind without selection or criticism (free association), no matter how trivial, embarrassing, or apparently irrelevant

Text Evidence:
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Interpretation should be given only when the material is near consciousness and strong resistance has been overcome; premature interpretation provokes increased resistance and is therapeutically counterproductive

Text Evidence:
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
The castration complex in boys (fear of losing the penis as punishment) and penis envy in girls (resentment at lacking the male organ) are universal phenomena arising from phallic stage experiences and profoundly shape subsequent development

Year: N/A
Domain: N/A

Text Evidence:
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Female sexual development is more complicated than male development because girls must change both their leading erotogenic zone (from clitoris to vagina) and their love-object (from mother to father), making them more vulnerable to developmental disturbances

Year: N/A
Domain: N/A

Text Evidence:
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
The concept of psychical reality distinguishes the reality of unconscious phantasies and wishes, which have causal efficacy in producing symptoms, from material reality; phantasies are psychically real even when materially false

Year: N/A
Domain: N/A

Text Evidence:
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
The unconscious system operates according to primary process (disregarding logic, allowing contradictions, timeless, replacing external by psychical reality), while the preconscious/conscious operates by secondary process (logical, temporal, reality-oriented)

Affects and emotions become detached from their original ideational content through repression and may attach to different ideas, explaining why people often have strong feelings whose origin they cannot identify

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Reaction-formation produces traits that are the opposite of repressed instinctual aims (e.g., excessive cleanliness as defense against anal-erotic impulses, excessive sympathy as defense against cruelty)

Isolation in obsessional neurosis separates an idea from its affect, allowing the idea to remain conscious while the associated feeling is repressed, producing apparently emotionless thoughts about disturbing content

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Ambivalence (simultaneous love and hate toward the same object) is particularly intense at the sadistic-anal stage and is characteristic of obsessional neurosis where it produces doubting, indecision, and opposing compulsions

The talking cure works because putting things into words creates an avenue from unconscious to conscious, and words themselves are derivatives of preconscious processes that can bridge the gap between systems

The negative therapeutic reaction occurs when clinical improvement produces increased guilt and self-punishment in some patients, paradoxically making them worse when treatment succeeds

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Education should aim to help the child find a middle path between unrestricted instinctual expression (which would make civilization impossible) and excessive repression (which produces neurosis)

Year: N/A
Domain: N/A

Text Evidence:
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
The therapeutic aim is not to eliminate conflict but to help the ego make better choices about managing conflicts, replacing pathological solutions (symptoms) with adaptive ones (reality satisfactions, sublimations)

================================================================================

Character traits are precipitates of abandoned object-cathexes, formed when the ego responds to loss of an object by identifying with it and taking on its characteristics

The constitutional factor (innate variations in instinctual strength, capacity for sublimation, ego resilience) always plays a role in neurosis aetiology and explains why similar experiences produce different outcomes in different individuals

================================================================================

Domain: N/A

Text Evidence:
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Dementia praecox (schizophrenia) involves profound narcissistic withdrawal where libido is retracted from objects and turned inward to such degree that reality-contact is lost and internal phantasy world becomes predominant

================================================================================
POSITION 3,267 of 6,391
================================================================================

ID: N/A
Collection: PRIMARY
Title: Melancholia results when loss of an object is handled not by mourning but by nar...
Work: INTRODUCTORY LECTURES ON PSYCHO-ANALYSIS
Year: N/A
Domain: N/A

Text Evidence:
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Melancholia results when loss of an object is handled not by mourning but by narcissistic identification, with the ego setting up the lost object inside itself and then directing ambivalent feelings (particularly hatred) against this internalized object, thus attacking itself

================================================================================

Year: N/A
Domain: N/A

Text Evidence:
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Normal mourning and pathological melancholia share the feature of reaction to object-loss, but mourning works through the loss gradually while melancholia involves regression to narcissistic identification

Transference is not created by analysis but merely uncovered by it; it arises spontaneously in all human relationships and is particularly intense in neurotics, whose capacity for object-love has been impaired by fixation to infantile objects

Year: N/A
Domain: N/A

Text Evidence:
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Positive transference (affectionate feelings toward the analyst) can be divided into conscious friendly feelings, which are unobjectionable and maintain the therapeutic alliance, and unconscious erotic feelings, which become resistance when they push for gratification rather than understanding

================================================================================

Work: Introductory Lectures on Psycho-Analysis, Lecture XXVII: Transference (1917)
Year: N/A
Domain: N/A

Text Evidence:
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Negative transference (hostile feelings toward the analyst) and the erotic component of positive transference constitute the transference-resistance: they obstruct the work by demanding emotional gratification instead of intellectual understanding and remembering

Psycho-analytic treatment makes far greater demands on the patient and the physician than suggestive therapy: it requires the patient's active intellectual participation and the physician's understanding of unconscious processes, and it is lengthy, laborious, and often unpleasant

Psycho-analysis cannot alter hereditary disposition or undo childhood experiences; it can only address the third factor in neurotic causation - real frustration in adult life - by helping the patient redistribute libido more advantageously and overcome internal obstacles to satisfaction

Primary gain from illness is the advantage of escaping from internal conflict through symptom-formation; secondary gain comprises all external advantages subsequently accruing from being ill - sympathy, reduced expectations, compensation, relief from duties

Work: Introductory Lectures on Psycho-Analysis, Lecture XXVIII: Analytic Therapy (1917)
Year: N/A
Domain: N/A

Text Evidence:
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
The accusation that psycho-analytic findings are artifacts of suggestion is refuted by three facts: analyses produce uniform findings across different analysts and patients, patients regularly resist rather than accept suggestions, and the same unconscious mechanisms are found in non-therapeutic contexts (dreams, parapraxes, folklore)

The ego is not a trustworthy or impartial agency in judging the neurosis: it is the very power that has created repressions and maintains them, so accepting the ego's account would mean judging the dispute by the victorious party, inevitably leading to error

Traumatic neuroses, particularly war neuroses, demonstrate a self-interested motive on the part of the ego seeking protection and advantage: the ego assents to the illness and maintains it when recovery would expose it again to the dangers that precipitated the neurosis

POSITION 3,351 of 6,391

Year: N/A
Domain: N/A

Text Evidence:
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
The narcissistic neuroses (dementia praecox, paranoia, melancholia) demonstrate that the ego can become the object of libidinal cathexis: in these conditions, libido withdrawn from the external world and objects is redirected to the ego itself, producing megalomania and loss of reality-testing

================================================================================
POSITION 3,352 of 6,391

Year: N/A
Domain: N/A

Text Evidence:
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Sleep represents a temporary return to primary narcissism: the sleeper withdraws libidinal cathexes from objects and the external world, concentrating them on the wish to sleep; this narcissistic withdrawal accounts for the hallucinatory character of dreams and the sleeper's indifference to reality

================================================================================

Physical illness causes a withdrawal of libido from objects back to the ego (hypochondriacal cathexis of the affected organ); during illness, the patient becomes narcissistic, withdraws interest from the external world, ceases to love, and concentrates on bodily sensations

POSITION 3,710 of 6,391
================================================================================

ID: N/A
Collection: PRIMARY
Title: popular psychologists talk of the splitting of peoples egos, what they are thinking of is this division (in the sphere of ego-psychology) between the
Work: The 'Uncanny'
Year: N/A
Domain: N/A

Text Evidence:
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
popular psychologists talk of the splitting of peoples egos, what they are thinking of is this division (in the sphere of ego-psychology) between the critical agency and the rest of the ego, and not the antithesis discovered by psycho-analysis between the ego and what is unconscious and repressed. It is true that the distinction between these two antitheses is to some extent effaced by the circumstance that foremost among the things that are rejected by the criticism of the ego are derivatives of the repressed.

================================================================================
POSITION 3,711 of 6,391
================================================================================

ID: N/A
Collection: PRIMARY
Title: observe what the effect is of meeting ones own image unbidden and unexpected. Ernst Mach has related two such observations in his Analyse der Empfind
Work: The 'Uncanny'
Year: N/A
Domain: N/A

Text Evidence:
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
observe what the effect is of meeting ones own image unbidden and unexpected. Ernst Mach has related two such observations in his Analyse der Empfindungen (1900, 3). On the first occasion he was not a little startled when he realized that the face before him was his own.The second time he formed a very unfavourable opinion about the supposed stranger who entered the omnibus, and thought What a shabby-looking school-master that man is who is getting in! - I can report a similar adventure. I was sitting alone in my wagon-lit compartment when a more than usually violent jolt of the train swung back the door of the adjoining washing-cabinet, and an elderly gentleman in a dressing-gown and a travelling cap came in. I assumed that in leaving the washing-cabinet, which lay between the two compartments, he had taken the wrong direction and come into my compartment by mistake.

================================================================================
POSITION 3,712 of 6,391
================================================================================

ID: N/A
Collection: PRIMARY
Title: Ernst Mach has related two such observations in his Analyse der Empfindungen (1900, 3). On the first occasion he was not a little startled when he rea
Work: The 'Uncanny'
Year: N/A
Domain: N/A

Text Evidence:
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Ernst Mach has related two such observations in his Analyse der Empfindungen (1900, 3). On the first occasion he was not a little startled when he realized that the face before him was his own.The second time he formed a very unfavourable opinion about the supposed stranger who entered the omnibus, and thought What a shabby-looking school-master that man is who is getting in! - I can report a similar adventure. I was sitting alone in my wagon-lit compartment when a more than usually violent jolt of the train swung back the door of the adjoining washing-cabinet, and an elderly gentleman in a dressing-gown and a travelling cap came in. I assumed that in leaving the washing-cabinet, which lay between the two compartments, he had taken the wrong direction and come into my compartment by mistake. Jumping up with the intention of putting him right, I at once realized to my dismay that the intruder was nothing but my own reflection in the looking-glass on the open door.

POSITION 3,713 of 6,391

ID: N/A
Collection: PRIMARY
Title: On the first occasion he was not a little startled when he realized that the face before him was his own.The second time he formed a very unfavourable
Work: The 'Uncanny'
Year: N/A
Domain: N/A

Text Evidence:
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
On the first occasion he was not a little startled when he realized that the face before him was his own.The second time he formed a very unfavourable opinion about the supposed stranger who entered the omnibus, and thought What a shabby-looking school-master that man is who is getting in! - I can report a similar adventure. I was sitting alone in my wagon-lit compartment when a more than usually violent jolt of the train swung back the door of the adjoining washing-cabinet, and an elderly gentleman in a dressing-gown and a travelling cap came in. I assumed that in leaving the washing-cabinet, which lay between the two compartments, he had taken the wrong direction and come into my compartment by mistake. Jumping up with the intention of putting him right, I at once realized to my dismay that the intruder was nothing but my own reflection in the looking-glass on the open door. I can still recollect that I thoroughly disliked his appearance.

================================================================================
POSITION 3,714 of 6,391
================================================================================

ID: N/A
Collection: PRIMARY
Title: I was sitting alone in my wagon-lit compartment when a more than usually violent jolt of the train swung back the door of the adjoining washing-cabine
Work: The 'Uncanny'
Year: N/A
Domain: N/A

Text Evidence:
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
I was sitting alone in my wagon-lit compartment when a more than usually violent jolt of the train swung back the door of the adjoining washing-cabinet, and an elderly gentleman in a dressing-gown and a travelling cap came in. I assumed that in leaving the washing-cabinet, which lay between the two compartments, he had taken the wrong direction and come into my compartment by mistake. Jumping up with the intention of putting him right, I at once realized to my dismay that the intruder was nothing but my own reflection in the looking-glass on the open door. I can still recollect that I thoroughly disliked his appearance. Instead, therefore, of being frightened by our doubles, both Mach and I simply failed to recognize them as such.

================================================================================
POSITION 3,715 of 6,391
================================================================================

ID: N/A
Collection: PRIMARY
Title: I assumed that in leaving the washing-cabinet, which lay between the two compartments, he had taken the wrong direction and come into my compartment b
Work: The 'Uncanny'
Year: N/A
Domain: N/A

Text Evidence:
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
I assumed that in leaving the washing-cabinet, which lay between the two compartments, he had taken the wrong direction and come into my compartment by mistake. Jumping up with the intention of putting him right, I at once realized to my dismay that the intruder was nothing but my own reflection in the looking-glass on the open door. I can still recollect that I thoroughly disliked his appearance. Instead, therefore, of being frightened by our doubles, both Mach and I simply failed to recognize them as such. Is it not possible, though, that our dislike of them was a vestigial trace of the archaic reaction which feels the double to be something uncanny?

================================================================================

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
observe what the effect is of meeting ones own image unbidden and unexpected. Ernst Mach has related two such observations in his Analyse der Empfindungen (1900, 3). On the first occasion he was not a little startled when he realized that the face before him was his own.The second time he formed a very unfavourable opinion about the supposed stranger who entered the omnibus, and thought What a shabby-looking school-master that man is who is getting in! - I can report a similar adventure. I was sitting alone in my wagon-lit compartment when a more than usually violent jolt of the train swung back the door of the adjoining washing-cabinet, and an elderly gentleman in a dressing-gown and a travelling cap came in. I assumed that in leaving the washing-cabinet, which lay between the two compartments, he had taken the wrong direction and come into my compartment by mistake. Jumping up with the intention of putting him right, I at once realized to my dismay that the intruder was nothing but my own reflection in the looking-glass on the open door. I can still recollect that I thoroughly disliked his appearance. Instead, therefore, of being frightened by our doubles, both Mach and I simply failed to recognize them as such. Is it not possible, though, that our dislike of them was a vestigial trace of the archaic reaction which feels the double to be something uncanny?

I assumed that in leaving the washing-cabinet, which lay between the two compartments, he had taken the wrong direction and come into my compartment by mistake. Jumping up with the intention of putting him right, I at once realized to my dismay that the intruder was nothing but my own reflection in the looking-glass on the open door. I can still recollect that I thoroughly disliked his appearance. Instead, therefore, of being frightened by our doubles, both Mach and I simply failed to recognize them as such. Is it not possible, though, that our dislike of them was a vestigial trace of the archaic reaction which feels the double to be something uncanny?

POSITION 3,720 of 6,391
================================================================================

ID: N/A
Collection: PRIMARY
Title: [Freud also translated one of Putnams papers (1910) anonymously and added the following footnote to the translation (Zbl. Psychoan., 1 (1911), 137): 
Work: The 'Uncanny'
Year: N/A
Domain: N/A

Text Evidence:
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
[Freud also translated one of Putnams papers (1910) anonymously and added the following footnote to the translation (Zbl. Psychoan., 1 (1911), 137): This lecture delivered by the Professor of Neurology at Boston University is offered to our readers as an offset to the many unjust and uncomprehending attacks that are levelled against psycho-analysis, in place of counter-criticisms which might easily lead to embittered feelings. J. Putnam is not only one of the most eminent neurologists in America but also a man everywhere greatly respected for hisunimpeachable character and high moral standards. Although he has left his youth far behind him, he took his open stand last year in the front rank of the champions of psycho-analysis.]

================================================================================
POSITION 3,721 of 6,391
================================================================================

ID: N/A
Collection: PRIMARY
Title: mother had been away for several hours and on her return was met with the words Baby o-o- o-o! which was at first incomprehensible. It soon turned o
Work: Beyond The Pleasure Principle
Year: N/A
Domain: N/A

Text Evidence:
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
mother had been away for several hours and on her return was met with the words Baby o-o- o-o! which was at first incomprehensible. It soon turned out, however, that during this long period of solitude the child had found a method of making himself disappear. He had discovered his reflection in a full-length mirror which did not quite reach to the ground, so that by crouching down he could make his mirror-image gone.

================================================================================
POSITION 3,722 of 6,391
================================================================================

ID: N/A
Collection: PRIMARY
Title: (1912) in an instructive and interesting paper which, however, is unfortunately not entirely clear to me. She there describes the sadistic components 
Work: Beyond The Pleasure Principle
Year: N/A
Domain: N/A

Text Evidence:
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
(1912) in an instructive and interesting paper which, however, is unfortunately not entirely clear to me. She there describes the sadistic components of the sexual instinct as destructive. A. Strke (1914), again, has attempted to identify the concept of libido itself with the biological concept (assumed on theoretical grounds) of an impetus towards death. See also Rank (1907). All these discussions, like that in the text, give evidence of the demand for a clarification of the theory of the instincts such as has not yet been achieved.

================================================================================

origin of the Platonic myth, which I give partly in his own words. It is to be remarked that what is essentially the same theory is already to be found in the Upanishads. For we find the following passage in the Brihadranyaka-upanishad, 1, 4, 3, where the origin of the world from the Atman (the Self or Ego) is described: But he felt no delight. Therefore a man who is lonely feels no delight. He wished for a second.

POSITION 3,725 of 6,391

ID: N/A
Collection: PRIMARY
Title: For we find the following passage in the Brihadranyaka-upanishad, 1, 4, 3, where the origin of the world from the Atman (the Self or Ego) is describe
Work: Beyond The Pleasure Principle
Year: N/A
Domain: N/A

Text Evidence:
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
For we find the following passage in the Brihadranyaka-upanishad, 1, 4, 3, where the origin of the world from the Atman (the Self or Ego) is described: But he felt no delight. Therefore a man who is lonely feels no delight. He wished for a second. He was so large as man and wife together. He then made this his Self to fall in two, and then arose husband and wife Therefore Yagnavalkya said: "We two are thus (each of us) like half a shell." Therefore the void which was there, is filled by the wife. The Brihadranyaka-upanishad is the most ancient of all the Upanishads and no competent authority dates it later than about the year 800 B.C.

================================================================================
POSITION 3,726 of 6,391

Therefore a man who is lonely feels no delight. He wished for a second. He was so large as man and wife together. He then made this his Self to fall in two, and then arose husband and wife Therefore Yagnavalkya said: "We two are thus (each of us) like half a shell." Therefore the void which was there, is filled by the wife. The Brihadranyaka-upanishad is the most ancient of all the Upanishads and no competent authority dates it later than about the year 800 B.C. In contradiction to the prevailing opinion, I should hesitate to give an unqualified denial to the possibility of Platos myth being derived, even if it were only indirectly, from the Indian source, since a similar possibility cannot be excluded in the case of the doctrine of transmigration.

POSITION 3,727 of 6,391

ID: N/A

Title: He wished for a second. He was so large as man and wife together. He then made this his Self to fall in two, and then arose husband and wife Therefore
Work: Beyond The Pleasure Principle
Year: N/A
Domain: N/A

Text Evidence:
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
He wished for a second. He was so large as man and wife together. He then made this his Self to fall in two, and then arose husband and wife Therefore Yagnavalkya said: "We two are thus (each of us) like half a shell." Therefore the void which was there, is filled by the wife. The Brihadranyaka-upanishad is the most ancient of all the Upanishads and no competent authority dates it later than about the year 800 B.C. In contradiction to the prevailing opinion, I should hesitate to give an unqualified denial to the possibility of Platos myth being derived, even if it were only indirectly, from the Indian source, since a similar possibility cannot be excluded in the case of the doctrine of transmigration. But even if a derivation of this kind (through the Pythagoreans in the first instance) were established, the significance of the coincidence between the two trains of thought would scarcely be diminished.

Work: Beyond The Pleasure Principle

He was so large as man and wife together. He then made this his Self to fall in two, and then arose husband and wife Therefore Yagnavalkya said: "We two are thus (each of us) like half a shell." Therefore the void which was there, is filled by the wife. The Brihadranyaka-upanishad is the most ancient of all the Upanishads and no competent authority dates it later than about the year 800 B.C. In contradiction to the prevailing opinion, I should hesitate to give an unqualified denial to the possibility of Platos myth being derived, even if it were only indirectly, from the Indian source, since a similar possibility cannot be excluded in the case of the doctrine of transmigration. But even if a derivation of this kind (through the Pythagoreans in the first instance) were established, the significance of the coincidence between the two trains of thought would scarcely be diminished. For Plato would not have adopted a story of this kind which had somehow reached him through some oriental tradition - to say nothing of giving it so important a place - unless it had struck him as containing an element of truth.

He then made this his Self to fall in two, and then arose husband and wife Therefore Yagnavalkya said: "We two are thus (each of us) like half a shell." Therefore the void which was there, is filled by the wife. The Brihadranyaka-upanishad is the most ancient of all the Upanishads and no competent authority dates it later than about the year 800 B.C. In contradiction to the prevailing opinion, I should hesitate to give an unqualified denial to the possibility of Platos myth being derived, even if it were only indirectly, from the Indian source, since a similar possibility cannot be excluded in the case of the doctrine of transmigration. But even if a derivation of this kind (through the Pythagoreans in the first instance) were established, the significance of the coincidence between the two trains of thought would scarcely be diminished. For Plato would not have adopted a story of this kind which had somehow reached him through some oriental tradition - to say nothing of giving it so important a place - unless it had struck him as containing an element of truth. In a paper devoted to a systematic examination of this line of thought before the time of Plato, Ziegler (1913) traces it back to Babylonian origins.

origin of the Platonic myth, which I give partly in his own words. It is to be remarked that what is essentially the same theory is already to be found in the Upanishads. POSITION 3,735 of 6,391
================================================================================

ID: N/A
Collection: PRIMARY
Title: in the course of the present work. We came to know what the sexual instincts were from their relation to the sexes and to the reproductive function.
Work: Beyond The Pleasure Principle
Year: N/A
Domain: N/A

Text Evidence:
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
in the course of the present work. We came to know what the sexual instincts were from their relation to the sexes and to the reproductive function. We retained this name after we had been obliged by the findings of psycho-analysis to connect them less closely with reproduction. With the hypothesis of narcissistic libido and the extension of the concept of libido to the individual cells, the sexual instinct was transformed for us into Eros, which seeks to force together and hold together the portions of living substance. What are commonly called the sexual instincts are looked upon by us as the part of Eros which is directed towards objects.

================================================================================
POSITION 3,736 of 6,391
================================================================================

ID: N/A
Collection: PRIMARY
Title: We came to know what the sexual instincts were from their relation to the sexes and to the reproductive function. We retained this name after we had
Work: Beyond The Pleasure Principle
Year: N/A
Domain: N/A

Text Evidence:
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
We came to know what the sexual instincts were from their relation to the sexes and to the reproductive function. We retained this name after we had been obliged by the findings of psycho-analysis to connect them less closely with reproduction. With the hypothesis of narcissistic libido and the extension of the concept of libido to the individual cells, the sexual instinct was transformed for us into Eros, which seeks to force together and hold together the portions of living substance. What are commonly called the sexual instincts are looked upon by us as the part of Eros which is directed towards objects. Our speculations have suggested that Eros operates from the beginning of life and appears as a life instinct in opposition to the death instinct which was brought into being by the coming to life of inorganic substance.

================================================================================

Work: Beyond The Pleasure Principle
Year: N/A

Text Evidence:
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
We retained this name after we had been obliged by the findings of psycho-analysis to connect them less closely with reproduction. With the hypothesis of narcissistic libido and the extension of the concept of libido to the individual cells, the sexual instinct was transformed for us into Eros, which seeks to force together and hold together the portions of living substance. What are commonly called the sexual instincts are looked upon by us as the part of Eros which is directed towards objects. Our speculations have suggested that Eros operates from the beginning of life and appears as a life instinct in opposition to the death instinct which was brought into being by the coming to life of inorganic substance. These speculations seek to solve the riddle of life by supposing that these two instincts were struggling with each other from the very first.

With the hypothesis of narcissistic libido and the extension of the concept of libido to the individual cells, the sexual instinct was transformed for us into Eros, which seeks to force together and hold together the portions of living substance. What are commonly called the sexual instincts are looked upon by us as the part of Eros which is directed towards objects. Our speculations have suggested that Eros operates from the beginning of life and appears as a life instinct in opposition to the death instinct which was brought into being by the coming to life of inorganic substance. These speculations seek to solve the riddle of life by supposing that these two instincts were struggling with each other from the very first. It is not so easy, perhaps, to follow the transformations though which the concept of the ego-instincts has passed.

POSITION 3,739 of 6,391
================================================================================

ID: N/A
Collection: PRIMARY
Title: What are commonly called the sexual instincts are looked upon by us as the part of Eros which is directed towards objects. Our speculations have sugge
Work: Beyond The Pleasure Principle
Year: N/A
Domain: N/A

Text Evidence:
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
What are commonly called the sexual instincts are looked upon by us as the part of Eros which is directed towards objects. Our speculations have suggested that Eros operates from the beginning of life and appears as a life instinct in opposition to the death instinct which was brought into being by the coming to life of inorganic substance. These speculations seek to solve the riddle of life by supposing that these two instincts were struggling with each other from the very first. It is not so easy, perhaps, to follow the transformations though which the concept of the ego-instincts has passed. To begin with we applied that name to all the instinctual trends (of which we had no closer knowledge) which could be distinguished from the sexual instincts directed towards an object; and we opposed the ego-instincts to the sexual instincts of which the libido is the manifestation.

================================================================================
POSITION 3,740 of 6,391
================================================================================

ID: N/A
Collection: PRIMARY
Title: Our speculations have suggested that Eros operates from the beginning of life and appears as a life instinct in opposition to the death instinct w
Work: Beyond The Pleasure Principle
Year: N/A
Domain: N/A

Text Evidence:
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Our speculations have suggested that Eros operates from the beginning of life and appears as a life instinct in opposition to the death instinct which was brought into being by the coming to life of inorganic substance. These speculations seek to solve the riddle of life by supposing that these two instincts were struggling with each other from the very first. It is not so easy, perhaps, to follow the transformations though which the concept of the ego-instincts has passed. To begin with we applied that name to all the instinctual trends (of which we had no closer knowledge) which could be distinguished from the sexual instincts directed towards an object; and we opposed the ego-instincts to the sexual instincts of which the libido is the manifestation. Subsequently we came to closer grips with the analysis of the ego and recognized that a portion of the ego-instincts is also of a libidinal character and has taken the subjects own ego as its object.

================================================================================

These speculations seek to solve the riddle of life by supposing that these two instincts were struggling with each other from the very first. It is not so easy, perhaps, to follow the transformations though which the concept of the ego-instincts has passed. To begin with we applied that name to all the instinctual trends (of which we had no closer knowledge) which could be distinguished from the sexual instincts directed towards an object; and we opposed the ego-instincts to the sexual instincts of which the libido is the manifestation. Subsequently we came to closer grips with the analysis of the ego and recognized that a portion of the ego-instincts is also of a libidinal character and has taken the subjects own ego as its object. These narcissistic self-preservative instincts had thenceforward to be counted among the libidinal sexual instincts.

It is not so easy, perhaps, to follow the transformations though which the concept of the ego-instincts has passed. To begin with we applied that name to all the instinctual trends (of which we had no closer knowledge) which could be distinguished from the sexual instincts directed towards an object; and we opposed the ego-instincts to the sexual instincts of which the libido is the manifestation. Subsequently we came to closer grips with the analysis of the ego and recognized that a portion of the ego-instincts is also of a libidinal character and has taken the subjects own ego as its object. These narcissistic self-preservative instincts had thenceforward to be counted among the libidinal sexual instincts. The opposition between the ego-instincts and the sexual instincts was transformed into one between the ego-instincts and the object-instincts, both of a libidinal nature.

POSITION 3,743 of 6,391
================================================================================

ID: N/A
Collection: PRIMARY
Title: To begin with we applied that name to all the instinctual trends (of which we had no closer knowledge) which could be distinguished from the sexual in
Work: Beyond The Pleasure Principle
Year: N/A
Domain: N/A

Text Evidence:
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
To begin with we applied that name to all the instinctual trends (of which we had no closer knowledge) which could be distinguished from the sexual instincts directed towards an object; and we opposed the ego-instincts to the sexual instincts of which the libido is the manifestation. Subsequently we came to closer grips with the analysis of the ego and recognized that a portion of the ego-instincts is also of a libidinal character and has taken the subjects own ego as its object. These narcissistic self-preservative instincts had thenceforward to be counted among the libidinal sexual instincts. The opposition between the ego-instincts and the sexual instincts was transformed into one between the ego-instincts and the object-instincts, both of a libidinal nature. But in its place a fresh opposition appeared between the libidinal (ego- and object-) instincts and others, which must be presumed to be present in the ego and which may perhaps actually be observed in the destructive instincts.

================================================================================

Subsequently we came to closer grips with the analysis of the ego and recognized that a portion of the ego-instincts is also of a libidinal character and has taken the subjects own ego as its object. These narcissistic self-preservative instincts had thenceforward to be counted among the libidinal sexual instincts. The opposition between the ego-instincts and the sexual instincts was transformed into one between the ego-instincts and the object-instincts, both of a libidinal nature. But in its place a fresh opposition appeared between the libidinal (ego- and object-) instincts and others, which must be presumed to be present in the ego and which may perhaps actually be observed in the destructive instincts. Our speculations have transformed this opposition into one between the life instincts (Eros) and the death instincts.

POSITION 3,747 of 6,391
================================================================================

ID: N/A
Collection: PRIMARY
Title: in the course of the present work. We came to know what the sexual instincts were from their relation to the sexes and to the reproductive function.
Work: Beyond The Pleasure Principle
Year: N/A
Domain: N/A

Text Evidence:
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
in the course of the present work. We came to know what the sexual instincts were from their relation to the sexes and to the reproductive function. We retained this name after we had been obliged by the findings of psycho-analysis to connect them less closely with reproduction. With the hypothesis of narcissistic libido and the extension of the concept of libido to the individual cells, the sexual instinct was transformed for us into Eros, which seeks to force together and hold together the portions of living substance. What are commonly called the sexual instincts are looked upon by us as the part of Eros which is directed towards objects. Our speculations have suggested that Eros operates from the beginning of life and appears as a life instinct in opposition to the death instinct which was brought into being by the coming to life of inorganic substance. These speculations seek to solve the riddle of life by supposing that these two instincts were struggling with each other from the very first. It is not so easy, perhaps, to follow the transformations though which the concept of the ego-instincts has passed. To begin with we applied that name to all the instinctual trends (of which we had no closer knowledge) which could be distinguished from the sexual instincts directed towards an object; and we opposed the ego-instincts to the sexual instincts of which the libido is the manifestation. Subsequently we came to closer grips with the analysis of the ego and recognized that a portion of the ego-instincts is also of a libidinal character and has taken the subjects own ego as its object.

================================================================================
POSITION 3,748 of 6,391
================================================================================

Work: Beyond The Pleasure Principle

Domain: N/A

Text Evidence:
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
With the hypothesis of narcissistic libido and the extension of the concept of libido to the individual cells, the sexual instinct was transformed for us into Eros, which seeks to force together and hold together the portions of living substance. What are commonly called the sexual instincts are looked upon by us as the part of Eros which is directed towards objects. Our speculations have suggested that Eros operates from the beginning of life and appears as a life instinct in opposition to the death instinct which was brought into being by the coming to life of inorganic substance. These speculations seek to solve the riddle of life by supposing that these two instincts were struggling with each other from the very first. It is not so easy, perhaps, to follow the transformations though which the concept of the ego-instincts has passed. To begin with we applied that name to all the instinctual trends (of which we had no closer knowledge) which could be distinguished from the sexual instincts directed towards an object; and we opposed the ego-instincts to the sexual instincts of which the libido is the manifestation. Subsequently we came to closer grips with the analysis of the ego and recognized that a portion of the ego-instincts is also of a libidinal character and has taken the subjects own ego as its object. These narcissistic self-preservative instincts had thenceforward to be counted among the libidinal sexual instincts. The opposition between the ego-instincts and the sexual instincts was transformed into one between the ego-instincts and the object-instincts, both of a libidinal nature. But in its place a fresh opposition appeared between the libidinal (ego- and object-) instincts and others, which must be presumed to be present in the ego and which may perhaps actually be observed in the destructive instincts.

================================================================================

POSITION 3,750 of 6,391
================================================================================

ID: N/A
Collection: PRIMARY
Title: in the course of the present work. We came to know what the sexual instincts were from their relation to the sexes and to the reproductive function.
Work: Beyond The Pleasure Principle
Year: N/A
Domain: N/A

Text Evidence:
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
in the course of the present work. We came to know what the sexual instincts were from their relation to the sexes and to the reproductive function. We retained this name after we had been obliged by the findings of psycho-analysis to connect them less closely with reproduction. With the hypothesis of narcissistic libido and the extension of the concept of libido to the individual cells, the sexual instinct was transformed for us into Eros, which seeks to force together and hold together the portions of living substance. What are commonly called the sexual instincts are looked upon by us as the part of Eros which is directed towards objects. Our speculations have suggested that Eros operates from the beginning of life and appears as a life instinct in opposition to the death instinct which was brought into being by the coming to life of inorganic substance. These speculations seek to solve the riddle of life by supposing that these two instincts were struggling with each other from the very first. It is not so easy, perhaps, to follow the transformations though which the concept of the ego-instincts has passed. To begin with we applied that name to all the instinctual trends (of which we had no closer knowledge) which could be distinguished from the sexual instincts directed towards an object; and we opposed the ego-instincts to the sexual instincts of which the libido is the manifestation. Subsequently we came to closer grips with the analysis of the ego and recognized that a portion of the ego-instincts is also of a libidinal character and has taken the subjects own ego as its object. These narcissistic self-preservative instincts had thenceforward to be counted among the libidinal sexual instincts. The opposition between the ego-instincts and the sexual instincts was transformed into one between the ego-instincts and the object-instincts, both of a libidinal nature. But in its place a fresh opposition appeared between the libidinal (ego- and object-) instincts and others, which must be presumed to be present in the ego and which may perhaps actually be observed in the destructive instincts. Our speculations have transformed this opposition into one between the life instincts (Eros) and the death instincts.

================================================================================
POSITION 3,751 of 6,391
================================================================================

ID: N/A
Collection: PRIMARY
Title: unconscious not quite coinciding with the one adopted by psycho-analysis. Le Bons unconscious more especially contains the most deeply buried feature
Work: Group Psychology And The Analysis Of The Ego
Year: N/A
Domain: N/A

Text Evidence:
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
unconscious not quite coinciding with the one adopted by psycho-analysis. Le Bons unconscious more especially contains the most deeply buried features of the racial mind, which as a matter of fact lies outside the scope of psycho-analysis. We do not fail to recognize, indeed, that the egos nucleus, which comprises the archaic heritage of the human mind, is unconscious; but in addition to this we distinguish the unconscious repressed, which arose from a portion of that heritage. This concept of the repressed is not to be found in Le Bon.

================================================================================
POSITION 3,752 of 6,391
================================================================================

ID: N/A
Collection: PRIMARY
Title: unconscious mental life, we follow a technical rule of disregarding doubt and uncertainty in the narrative of the dream, and of treating every element
Work: Group Psychology And The Analysis Of The Ego
Year: N/A
Domain: N/A

Text Evidence:
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
unconscious mental life, we follow a technical rule of disregarding doubt and uncertainty in the narrative of the dream, and of treating every element of the manifest dream as being quite certain. We attribute doubt and uncertainty to the influence of the censorship to which the dream-work is subjected, and we assume that the primary dream-thoughts are not acquainted with doubt and uncertainty as critical processes. They may of course be present, like anything else, as part of the content of the days residues which lead to the dream.

================================================================================
POSITION 3,753 of 6,391
================================================================================

ID: N/A
Collection: PRIMARY
Title: the affective life of children, and it is present as well in dream life. Thanks to the isolation of the single emotions in the unconscious, a slight a
Work: Group Psychology And The Analysis Of The Ego
Year: N/A
Domain: N/A

Text Evidence:
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
the affective life of children, and it is present as well in dream life. Thanks to the isolation of the single emotions in the unconscious, a slight annoyance during the day will express itself ina dream as a wish for the offending persons death, or a breath of temptation may give the impetus to the portrayal in the dream of a criminal action. Hanns Sachs has made an appropriate remark on this point: If we look in our consciousness at something that has been told us by a dream about a contemporary (real) situation, we ought not to be surprised to find that the monster which we saw under the magnifying glass of analysis turns out to be a tiny

================================================================================
POSITION 3,754 of 6,391
================================================================================

ID: N/A
Collection: PRIMARY
Title: nearest to them exist side by side for a long time, without either of them interfering with the expression of the other and opposite one. If eventuall
Work: Group Psychology And The Analysis Of The Ego
Year: N/A
Domain: N/A

Text Evidence:
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
nearest to them exist side by side for a long time, without either of them interfering with the expression of the other and opposite one. If eventually a conflict breaks out between the two, it is often settled by the child making a change of object and displacing one of the ambivalent emotions on to a substitute. The history of the development of a neurosis in an adult will also show that a suppressed emotion may frequently persist for a long time in unconscious or even in conscious phantasies, the content of which naturally runs directly counter to some predominant tendency, and yet that this opposition does not result in any proceedings on the part of the ego against what it has repudiated. The phantasy is tolerated for quite a long time,until suddenly one day, usually as a result of an increase in the affective cathexis of the phantasy, a conflict breaks out between it and the ego with all the usual consequences. In the process of a childs development into a mature adult there is a more and more extensive integration of his personality, a co-ordination of the separate instinctual impulses and purposive trends which have grown up in him independently of one another.

================================================================================
POSITION 3,755 of 6,391
================================================================================

ID: N/A
Collection: PRIMARY
Title: If eventually a conflict breaks out between the two, it is often settled by the child making a change of object and displacing one of the ambivalent e
Work: Group Psychology And The Analysis Of The Ego
Year: N/A
Domain: N/A

Text Evidence:
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
If eventually a conflict breaks out between the two, it is often settled by the child making a change of object and displacing one of the ambivalent emotions on to a substitute. The history of the development of a neurosis in an adult will also show that a suppressed emotion may frequently persist for a long time in unconscious or even in conscious phantasies, the content of which naturally runs directly counter to some predominant tendency, and yet that this opposition does not result in any proceedings on the part of the ego against what it has repudiated. The phantasy is tolerated for quite a long time,until suddenly one day, usually as a result of an increase in the affective cathexis of the phantasy, a conflict breaks out between it and the ego with all the usual consequences. In the process of a childs development into a mature adult there is a more and more extensive integration of his personality, a co-ordination of the separate instinctual impulses and purposive trends which have grown up in him independently of one another. The analogous process in the domain of sexual life has long been known to us as the co-ordination of all the sexual instincts into a definitive genital organization. (Three Essays on the Theory of Sexuality, 1905d.) Moreover, that the unification of the ego is liable to the same interferences as that of the libido is shown by numerous familiar instances, such as that of men of science who have preserved their faith in the Bible, and other similar cases. - The various possible ways in which the ego can later disintegrate form a special chapter in psychopathology.

================================================================================

POSITION 3,759 of 6,391

ID: N/A
Collection: PRIMARY
Title: so as to profit by one anothers warmth and so save themselves from being frozen to death. But soon they felt one anothers quills, which induced them
Work: Group Psychology And The Analysis Of The Ego
Year: N/A
Domain: N/A

Text Evidence:
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
so as to profit by one anothers warmth and so save themselves from being frozen to death. But soon they felt one anothers quills, which induced them to separate again. And now, when the need for warmth brought them nearer together again, the second evil arose once more. So that they were driven backwards and forwards from one trouble to the other, until they had discovered a mean distance at which they could most tolerably exist. (Parerga und Paralipomena, Part II, 31, Gleichnisse und Parabeln.)

================================================================================
POSITION 3,760 of 6,391
================================================================================

ID: N/A
Collection: PRIMARY
Title: examples taken from pathology, and that we have consequently left part of the riddle of group formations untouched. A far more fundamental and compreh
Work: Group Psychology And The Analysis Of The Ego
Year: N/A
Domain: N/A

Text Evidence:
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
examples taken from pathology, and that we have consequently left part of the riddle of group formations untouched. A far more fundamental and comprehensive psychological analysis would have to intervene at this point. A path leads from identification by way of imitation to empathy, that is, to the comprehension of the mechanism by means of which we are enabled to take up any attitude at all towards another mental life. Moreover there is still much to be explained in the manifestations of existing identifications. These result among other things in a person limiting his aggressiveness towards those with whom he has identified himself, and in his sparing them and giving them help.

================================================================================
POSITION 3,761 of 6,391
================================================================================

ID: N/A
Collection: PRIMARY
Title: A far more fundamental and comprehensive psychological analysis would have to intervene at this point. A path leads from identification by way of imit
Work: Group Psychology And The Analysis Of The Ego
Year: N/A
Domain: N/A

Text Evidence:
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
A far more fundamental and comprehensive psychological analysis would have to intervene at this point. A path leads from identification by way of imitation to empathy, that is, to the comprehension of the mechanism by means of which we are enabled to take up any attitude at all towards another mental life. Moreover there is still much to be explained in the manifestations of existing identifications. These result among other things in a person limiting his aggressiveness towards those with whom he has identified himself, and in his sparing them and giving them help. The study of such identifications, like those, for instance which lie at the root of clan feeling, led Robertson Smith (Kinship and Marriage, 1885) to the surprising discovery that they rest upon the acknowledgement of the possession of a common substance, and may even therefore be created by a meal eaten in common.

================================================================================
POSITION 3,762 of 6,391
================================================================================

ID: N/A
Collection: PRIMARY
Title: A path leads from identification by way of imitation to empathy, that is, to the comprehension of the mechanism by means of which we are enabled to ta
Work: Group Psychology And The Analysis Of The Ego
Year: N/A
Domain: N/A

Text Evidence:
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
A path leads from identification by way of imitation to empathy, that is, to the comprehension of the mechanism by means of which we are enabled to take up any attitude at all towards another mental life. Moreover there is still much to be explained in the manifestations of existing identifications. These result among other things in a person limiting his aggressiveness towards those with whom he has identified himself, and in his sparing them and giving them help. The study of such identifications, like those, for instance which lie at the root of clan feeling, led Robertson Smith (Kinship and Marriage, 1885) to the surprising discovery that they rest upon the acknowledgement of the possession of a common substance, and may even therefore be created by a meal eaten in common. This feature makes it possible to connect this kind of identification with the early history of the human family which I constructed in Totem and Taboo.

POSITION 3,766 of 6,391
================================================================================

ID: N/A
Collection: PRIMARY
Title: especially to the primal horde. The will of the individual was too weak; he did not venture upon action. No impulses whatever came into existence exce
Work: Group Psychology And The Analysis Of The Ego
Year: N/A
Domain: N/A

Text Evidence:
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
especially to the primal horde. The will of the individual was too weak; he did not venture upon action. No impulses whatever came into existence except collective ones; there was only a common will, there were no single ones. An idea did not dare to turn itself into an act of will unless it felt itself reinforced by a perception of its general diffusion. This weakness of the idea is to be explained by the strength of the emotional tie which is shared by all the members of the horde; but the similarity in the circumstances of their life and the absence of any private property assist in determining the uniformity of their individual mental acts.

The will of the individual was too weak; he did not venture upon action. No impulses whatever came into existence except collective ones; there was only a common will, there were no single ones. An idea did not dare to turn itself into an act of will unless it felt itself reinforced by a perception of its general diffusion. This weakness of the idea is to be explained by the strength of the emotional tie which is shared by all the members of the horde; but the similarity in the circumstances of their life and the absence of any private property assist in determining the uniformity of their individual mental acts. As we may observe with children and soldiers, common activity is not excluded even in the excretory functions.

No impulses whatever came into existence except collective ones; there was only a common will, there were no single ones. An idea did not dare to turn itself into an act of will unless it felt itself reinforced by a perception of its general diffusion. This weakness of the idea is to be explained by the strength of the emotional tie which is shared by all the members of the horde; but the similarity in the circumstances of their life and the absence of any private property assist in determining the uniformity of their individual mental acts. As we may observe with children and soldiers, common activity is not excluded even in the excretory functions. The one great exception is provided by the sexual act, in which a third person is at best superfluous and in the extreme case is condemned to a state of painful expectancy.

================================================================================
POSITION 3,773 of 6,391
================================================================================

ID: N/A
Collection: PRIMARY
Title: hypnotist, while he is consciously occupied with monotonous and uninteresting perceptions, finds a parallel among the events of psycho-analytic treatm
Work: Group Psychology And The Analysis Of The Ego
Year: N/A
Domain: N/A

Text Evidence:
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
hypnotist, while he is consciously occupied with monotonous and uninteresting perceptions, finds a parallel among the events of psycho-analytic treatment, which deserves to be mentioned here. At least once in the course of every analysis a moment comes when the patient obstinately maintains that just now positively nothing whatever occurs to his mind. His free associations come to a stop and the usual incentives for putting them in motion fail in their effect. If the analyst insists, the patient is at last induced to admit that he is thinking of the view from the consulting-room window, of the wall-paper that he sees before him, or of the gas-lamp hanging from the ceiling. Then one knows at once that he has gone off into the transference and that he is engaged upon what are still unconscious thoughts relating to the physician; and one sees the stoppage in the patients associations disappear, as soon as he has been given this explanation.

================================================================================

================================================================================

POSITION 3,775 of 6,391
================================================================================

ID: N/A
Collection: PRIMARY
Title: His free associations come to a stop and the usual incentives for putting them in motion fail in their effect. If the analyst insists, the patient is 
Work: Group Psychology And The Analysis Of The Ego
Year: N/A
Domain: N/A

Text Evidence:
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
His free associations come to a stop and the usual incentives for putting them in motion fail in their effect. If the analyst insists, the patient is at last induced to admit that he is thinking of the view from the consulting-room window, of the wall-paper that he sees before him, or of the gas-lamp hanging from the ceiling. Then one knows at once that he has gone off into the transference and that he is engaged upon what are still unconscious thoughts relating to the physician; and one sees the stoppage in the patients associations disappear, as soon as he has been given this explanation.

================================================================================
POSITION 3,776 of 6,391
================================================================================

ID: N/A
Collection: PRIMARY
Title: induced us to give up Bernheims conception of hypnosis and go back to the naf earlier one. According to Bernheim all hypnotic phenomena are to be tr
Work: Group Psychology And The Analysis Of The Ego
Year: N/A
Domain: N/A

Text Evidence:
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
induced us to give up Bernheims conception of hypnosis and go back to the naf earlier one. According to Bernheim all hypnotic phenomena are to be traced to the factor of suggestion, which is not itself capable of further explanation. We have come to the conclusion that suggestion is a partial manifestation of the state of hypnosis, and that hypnosis is solidly founded upon a predisposition which has survived in the unconscious from the early history of the human family.

================================================================================
POSITION 3,777 of 6,391
================================================================================

ID: N/A
Collection: PRIMARY
Title: from investigation of the anamneses of neurotics. With the latter, however, they occur in early childhood, at the time of the early efflorescence of e
Work: Group Psychology And The Analysis Of The Ego
Year: N/A
Domain: N/A

Text Evidence:
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
from investigation of the anamneses of neurotics. With the latter, however, they occur in early childhood, at the time of the early efflorescence of erotic life; with our patient, who was in no way neurotic, they took place in the first years following puberty, though, incidentally, they were just as completely unconscious. Perhaps one day this temporal factor may turn out to be of great importance.

================================================================================
POSITION 3,778 of 6,391
================================================================================

ID: N/A
Collection: PRIMARY
Title: causes of homosexuality, or in the mechanism of libidinal fixation in general, I will adduce here another analytic observation of the same kind which 
Work: Group Psychology And The Analysis Of The Ego
Year: N/A
Domain: N/A

Text Evidence:
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
causes of homosexuality, or in the mechanism of libidinal fixation in general, I will adduce here another analytic observation of the same kind which has a special feature of interest. I once knew two twin brothers, both of whom were endowed with strong libidinal impulses. One of them was very successful with women, and had innumerable affairs with women and girls. The other went the same way at first, but it became unpleasant for him to be trespassing on his brothers preserves, and, owing to the likeness between them, to be mistaken for him on intimate occasions; so he got out of the difficulty by becoming homosexual. He left the women to his brother, and thus retired in his favour.

================================================================================
POSITION 3,779 of 6,391

Title: I once knew two twin brothers, both of whom were endowed with strong libidinal impulses. One of them was very successful with women, and had innumerab
Work: Group Psychology And The Analysis Of The Ego
Year: N/A
Domain: N/A

Text Evidence:
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
I once knew two twin brothers, both of whom were endowed with strong libidinal impulses. One of them was very successful with women, and had innumerable affairs with women and girls. The other went the same way at first, but it became unpleasant for him to be trespassing on his brothers preserves, and, owing to the likeness between them, to be mistaken for him on intimate occasions; so he got out of the difficulty by becoming homosexual. He left the women to his brother, and thus retired in his favour. Another time I treated a youngish man, an artist, unmistakably bisexual in disposition, in whom the homosexual trend had come to the fore simultaneously with a disturbance in his work.

The other went the same way at first, but it became unpleasant for him to be trespassing on his brothers preserves, and, owing to the likeness between them, to be mistaken for him on intimate occasions; so he got out of the difficulty by becoming homosexual.
