POSITION 3,781 of 6,391
================================================================================

ID: N/A
Collection: PRIMARY
Title: The other went the same way at first, but it became unpleasant for him to be trespassing on his brothers preserves, and, owing to the likeness betwee
Work: Group Psychology And The Analysis Of The Ego
Year: N/A
Domain: N/A

Text Evidence:
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
The other went the same way at first, but it became unpleasant for him to be trespassing on his brothers preserves, and, owing to the likeness between them, to be mistaken for him on intimate occasions; so he got out of the difficulty by becoming homosexual. He left the women to his brother, and thus retired in his favour. Another time I treated a youngish man, an artist, unmistakably bisexual in disposition, in whom the homosexual trend had come to the fore simultaneously with a disturbance in his work. He fled from both women and work together. The analysis, which was able to bring him back to both, showed that fear of his father was the most powerful psychical motive for both the disturbances, which were really renunciations.

================================================================================
POSITION 3,782 of 6,391
================================================================================

ID: N/A
Collection: PRIMARY
Title: He left the women to his brother, and thus retired in his favour. Another time I treated a youngish man, an artist, unmistakably bisexual in dispositi
Work: Group Psychology And The Analysis Of The Ego
Year: N/A
Domain: N/A

Text Evidence:
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
He left the women to his brother, and thus retired in his favour. Another time I treated a youngish man, an artist, unmistakably bisexual in disposition, in whom the homosexual trend had come to the fore simultaneously with a disturbance in his work. He fled from both women and work together. The analysis, which was able to bring him back to both, showed that fear of his father was the most powerful psychical motive for both the disturbances, which were really renunciations. In his imagination all women belonged to his father, and he sought refuge in men out of submission, so as to retire from the conflict with his father.

================================================================================
POSITION 3,783 of 6,391
================================================================================

ID: N/A
Collection: PRIMARY
Title: Another time I treated a youngish man, an artist, unmistakably bisexual in disposition, in whom the homosexual trend had come to the fore simultaneous
Work: Group Psychology And The Analysis Of The Ego
Year: N/A
Domain: N/A

Text Evidence:
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Another time I treated a youngish man, an artist, unmistakably bisexual in disposition, in whom the homosexual trend had come to the fore simultaneously with a disturbance in his work. He fled from both women and work together. The analysis, which was able to bring him back to both, showed that fear of his father was the most powerful psychical motive for both the disturbances, which were really renunciations. In his imagination all women belonged to his father, and he sought refuge in men out of submission, so as to retire from the conflict with his father. Such a motivation of the homosexual object-choice must be by no means uncommon; in the primaeval ages of the human race all women presumably belonged to the father and head of the primal horde.

================================================================================

In his imagination all women belonged to his father, and he sought refuge in men out of submission, so as to retire from the conflict with his father. Such a motivation of the homosexual object-choice must be by no means uncommon; in the primaeval ages of the human race all women presumably belonged to the father and head of the primal horde. Among brothers and sisters who are not twins this retiring plays a great part in other spheres as well as in that of erotic choice.

The analysis, which was able to bring him back to both, showed that fear of his father was the most powerful psychical motive for both the disturbances, which were really renunciations. In his imagination all women belonged to his father, and he sought refuge in men out of submission, so as to retire from the conflict with his father. Such a motivation of the homosexual object-choice must be by no means uncommon; in the primaeval ages of the human race all women presumably belonged to the father and head of the primal horde. Among brothers and sisters who are not twins this retiring plays a great part in other spheres as well as in that of erotic choice. For example, an elder brother studies music and isadmired for it; the younger, far more gifted musically, soon gives up his own musical studies, in spite of his fondness for it, and cannot be persuaded to touch an instrument again.

POSITION 3,786 of 6,391

ID: N/A
Collection: PRIMARY
Title: In his imagination all women belonged to his father, and he sought refuge in men out of submission, so as to retire from the conflict with his father.
Work: Group Psychology And The Analysis Of The Ego
Year: N/A
Domain: N/A

Text Evidence:
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
In his imagination all women belonged to his father, and he sought refuge in men out of submission, so as to retire from the conflict with his father. Such a motivation of the homosexual object-choice must be by no means uncommon; in the primaeval ages of the human race all women presumably belonged to the father and head of the primal horde. Among brothers and sisters who are not twins this retiring plays a great part in other spheres as well as in that of erotic choice. For example, an elder brother studies music and isadmired for it; the younger, far more gifted musically, soon gives up his own musical studies, in spite of his fondness for it, and cannot be persuaded to touch an instrument again. This is only one example of a very frequent occurrence, and investigation of the motives leading to this retirement rather than to open rivalry discloses very complicated conditions in the mind.

ID: N/A
Collection: PRIMARY
Title: causes of homosexuality, or in the mechanism of libidinal fixation in general, I will adduce here another analytic observation of the same kind which 
Work: Group Psychology And The Analysis Of The Ego
Year: N/A
Domain: N/A

Text Evidence:
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
causes of homosexuality, or in the mechanism of libidinal fixation in general, I will adduce here another analytic observation of the same kind which has a special feature of interest. I once knew two twin brothers, both of whom were endowed with strong libidinal impulses. One of them was very successful with women, and had innumerable affairs with women and girls. The other went the same way at first, but it became unpleasant for him to be trespassing on his brothers preserves, and, owing to the likeness between them, to be mistaken for him on intimate occasions; so he got out of the difficulty by becoming homosexual. He left the women to his brother, and thus retired in his favour. Another time I treated a youngish man, an artist, unmistakably bisexual in disposition, in whom the homosexual trend had come to the fore simultaneously with a disturbance in his work. He fled from both women and work together. The analysis, which was able to bring him back to both, showed that fear of his father was the most powerful psychical motive for both the disturbances, which were really renunciations. In his imagination all women belonged to his father, and he sought refuge in men out of submission, so as to retire from the conflict with his father. Such a motivation of the homosexual object-choice must be by no means uncommon; in the primaeval ages of the human race all women presumably belonged to the father and head of the primal horde.

ID: BPP-0025
Collection: EXTENDED
Title: System Bw characteristics from exposed position (immediate external contact)
Work: BEYOND THE PLEASURE PRINCIPLE

ID: FREUD-2329
Collection: EXTRACTED
Title: The Unconscious Mind
Work: Complete Works Part 1
Year: N/A
Domain: METAPSYCHOLOGY

Text Evidence:
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Freud posited that the unconscious mind plays a crucial role in influencing thoughts, feelings, and behaviors, often without the individual's awareness. This hidden part of the psyche contains repressed memories and desires that can manifest in dreams and symptoms of neurosis.

================================================================================

Collection: EXTRACTED
Title: Dreams as Wish Fulfillment
Work: Complete Works Part 1
Year: N/A
Domain: DREAM_THEORY

Text Evidence:
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Freud argued that dreams serve as a form of wish fulfillment, allowing individuals to express desires that are otherwise suppressed in waking life. He believed that analyzing dreams could reveal underlying conflicts and desires, providing insight into the unconscious.

Domain: DEVELOPMENTAL_THEORY

Text Evidence:
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Freud introduced the concept of psychosexual development, suggesting that personality develops through a series of stages centered on erogenous zones. Each stage, from oral to genital, plays a critical role in shaping adult personality and behavior.

Year: N/A
Domain: PSYCHOPATHOLOGY

Text Evidence:
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Freud identified various defense mechanisms that the ego employs to protect itself from anxiety and conflict. These mechanisms, such as repression, denial, and projection, help individuals cope with internal and external stressors by distorting reality.

Work: Complete Works Part 1
Year: N/A
Domain: DEVELOPMENTAL_THEORY

Text Evidence:
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Freud proposed the Oedipus complex as a central element of his theory of psychosexual development, where a child experiences unconscious desires for the opposite-sex parent and rivalry with the same-sex parent. This complex is pivotal in forming the child's identity and moral framework.

Collection: EXTRACTED
Title: Hysteria and Memory
Work: Complete Works Part 1
Year: N/A
Domain: PSYCHOPATHOLOGY

Text Evidence:
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Hysterics suffer mainly from reminiscences. The determining process continues to operate in some way or other for years, not indirectly, but as a directly releasing cause. This suggests that traumatic memories can have lasting effects on psychological well-being, indicating that unresolved past experiences can manifest as symptoms in the present.

Title: Memory Persistence
Work: Complete Works Part 1
Year: N/A
Domain: DEVELOPMENTAL_THEORY

Text Evidence:
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
It seems extraordinary that events experienced so long ago should continue to operate so intensely. The fading of a memory or the losing of its affect depends on various factors, particularly the energetic reaction to the event. This suggests that the emotional intensity of memories can affect their longevity and impact.

Title: Resistance in Psychotherapy
Work: Complete Works Part 2
Year: N/A
Domain: CLINICAL_THEORY

Text Evidence:
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Psychical resistance, especially one that has been in force for a long time, can only be resolved slowly and by degrees. We must wait patiently and utilize the intellectual interest that the patient begins to feel after working for a short time. By explaining things and giving information about psychical processes, we can make the patient a collaborator and push back their resistance.

POSITION 6,146 of 6,391
================================================================================

ID: FREUD-2539
Collection: EXTRACTED
Title: Hysteria as Multi-Dimensional Structure
Work: Complete Works Part 2
Year: N/A
Domain: PSYCHOPATHOLOGY

Text Evidence:
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Hysteria presents itself as a structure in several dimensions, stratified in at least three different ways. There is a nucleus of traumatic memories, surrounded by a profuse amount of other mnemic material arranged in a linear chronological order. This complexity complicates the analysis, as memories emerge in reverse order, with the freshest experiences appearing first.

================================================================================

Work: Complete Works Part 2
Year: N/A
Domain: CLINICAL_THEORY

Text Evidence:
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
The analysis reveals that memories are arranged in a chronological order, which is as trustworthy as the succession of days of the week. This order is crucial for understanding the patient's experiences and the development of their symptoms.

Collection: EXTRACTED
Title: Stratification of Memory Resistance
Work: Complete Works Part 2
Year: N/A
Domain: METAPSYCHOLOGY

Text Evidence:
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Memories are stratified concentrically around the pathogenic nucleus, with varying degrees of resistance. The closer the memories are to the nucleus, the more difficult they are to access, indicating a complex relationship between consciousness and repressed memories.

Work: Complete Works Part 2
Year: N/A
Domain: TECHNIQUE

Text Evidence:
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
The grouping of similar memories into collections, or 'themes', is a general feature of analysis. Each theme exhibits a stratified arrangement, characterized by equal degrees of resistance, which complicates the retrieval of deeper memories.

Title: Dreams Derive from Reality
Work: Complete Works Part 3
Year: N/A
Domain: DREAM_THEORY

Text Evidence:
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Freud posits that the content of dreams is fundamentally rooted in our experiences, whether they are external or internal. Dreams borrow their material from the real world and our intellectual life, suggesting that even the most fantastical elements in dreams are connected to our waking thoughts and experiences.

================================================================================
POSITION 6,151 of 6,391

Collection: EXTRACTED
Title: Memory's Role in Dream Content
Work: Complete Works Part 3
Year: N/A
Domain: PSYCHOPATHOLOGY

Text Evidence:
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Freud asserts that all dream content is derived from memory and experience, although the connection between dreams and reality may not be immediately apparent. The peculiarities of memory in dreams can obscure this relationship, leading to the mistaken belief that dreams are independently produced.

================================================================================

Text Evidence:
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Freud highlights that the relationship between dream content and waking reality often requires diligent exploration to uncover. Many times, the source of dream material may remain hidden until a subsequent experience triggers the memory, revealing the dream's connection to past events.

Collection: EXTRACTED
Title: Dreams Reflect Childhood Memories
Work: Complete Works Part 3
Year: N/A
Domain: DREAM_THEORY

Text Evidence:
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Freud discusses how dreams can reveal accurate memories from childhood, as illustrated by the example of Maury, who recalled a watchman from his father's bridge construction through a dream. This suggests that dreams can serve as a conduit for accessing repressed or forgotten memories from early life.

Year: N/A
Domain: DREAM_THEORY

Text Evidence:
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Freud shares a personal dream where he confused the image of a doctor from his childhood with a schoolmaster. This illustrates the complex connections that can exist between figures in dreams, revealing how our subconscious mind intertwines different memories and associations.

Text Evidence:

Freud discusses how dreams can be influenced by external sensory stimuli experienced during sleep. For instance, a sound or sensation can evoke dream imagery that corresponds to the stimulus, illustrating the connection between waking experiences and dream content.

Year: N/A
Domain: DREAM_THEORY

Text Evidence:
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Freud provides examples where physical sensations, such as discomfort or temperature changes, lead to specific dream scenarios. This suggests that our bodily experiences can shape the narrative and themes of our dreams, linking physical states to psychological experiences.

================================================================================
POSITION 6,160 of 6,391
================================================================================

ID: FREUD-2739
Collection: EXTRACTED
Title: Accidental Stimuli Create Dream Imagery
Work: Complete Works Part 3
Year: N/A
Domain: DREAM_THEORY

Text Evidence:
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Freud notes that accidental stimuli during sleep, like a straw between toes or a tight shirt, can manifest in dreams as vivid scenarios, such as being hanged or tortured. This highlights the role of chance occurrences in the formation of dream narratives.

================================================================================
POSITION 6,161 of 6,391
================================================================================

ID: FREUD-2740
Collection: EXTRACTED
Title: Dreams as Responses to Bodily States
Work: Complete Works Part 3
Year: N/A
Domain: DREAM_THEORY

Text Evidence:
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Freud illustrates that dreams often arise as responses to bodily conditions, such as pain or discomfort, which can lead to dreams of being attacked or injured. This emphasizes the interplay between physical sensations and the psychological processes involved in dreaming.

================================================================================

Domain: DREAM_THEORY

Text Evidence:
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
The analysis of nonsensical verbal forms in dreams reveals the dream works achievements in condensation, indicating that dreams often reflect underlying unconscious conflicts and emotions. This suggests that dreams are not random but are deeply connected to our psychological states.

Domain: PSYCHOPATHOLOGY

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
The verbal malformations in dreams resemble those found in paranoia, hysteria, and obsessions, suggesting a common source in the psychological processes of the mind. This highlights the intricate relationship between language and various psychological disorders.

Collection: EXTRACTED
Title: Commonality of Dream Material
Work: Complete Works Part 4
Year: N/A
Domain: DREAM_THEORY

Text Evidence:
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Freud notes that the material found in dreams, such as nonsensical verbal forms, is very common, yet often goes unrecorded due to the dependence of dream interpretation on psychoanalytic treatment, suggesting a wealth of unconscious material waiting to be explored.

POSITION 6,167 of 6,391
================================================================================

ID: FREUD-2934
Collection: EXTRACTED
Title: Dreams Have Meaning
Work: Complete Works Part 4
Year: N/A
Domain: DREAM_THEORY

Text Evidence:
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Freud asserts that dreams are full of meaning and should not be dismissed as nonsense. He emphasizes that understanding dreams requires attention from the dreamer, suggesting that even seemingly nonsensical dreams contain significant insights into the individual's psyche.

Text Evidence:

Freud notes that dreams often conceal unchaste or secret qualities of the dreamer, which complicates their interpretation. This suggests that the latent content of dreams can reveal deeper, often hidden aspects of one's personality and desires.

Title: Dream Analysis vs. Synthesis
Work: Complete Works Part 4
Year: N/A
Domain: CLINICAL_THEORY

Text Evidence:
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Freud differentiates between dream analysis and synthesis, stating that while analysis can be valuable even if incomplete, synthesis requires a complete understanding of the dream to be convincing. This highlights the methodological rigor he believes is necessary in psychoanalysis.

Work: Complete Works Part 4

Freud posits that the same individual exists whether awake or dreaming, suggesting a continuity of self that transcends the dream state. This idea reinforces the notion that dreams are integral to understanding the whole person.

================================================================================
POSITION 6,172 of 6,391
================================================================================

ID: FREUD-2939
Collection: EXTRACTED
Title: Causality in Dream Representation
Work: Complete Works Part 4
Year: N/A
Domain: DREAM_THEORY

Text Evidence:
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Freud argues that dreams represent causality through temporal sequences, either by a sequence of dreams or by the transformation of one image into another. However, he notes that in many cases, the causal relation is lost in the confusion of dream elements, and alternatives are often presented as equally valid rather than mutually exclusive.

================================================================================
POSITION 6,173 of 6,391
================================================================================

ID: FREUD-2940
Collection: EXTRACTED
Title: Ambiguity of Dream Elements
Work: Complete Works Part 4
Year: N/A
Domain: DREAM_THEORY

Text Evidence:
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Freud highlights that dream elements often possess a quality of vagueness, which can be resolved through interpretation. He suggests that when narrators use 'either-or' to describe dreams, it is more accurate to treat the alternatives as equally valid and link them with 'and', reflecting the complexity of dream thoughts.

Domain: PSYCHOPATHOLOGY

Text Evidence:
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
In the analysis of dreams, Freud indicates that they often fulfill multiple wishes or thoughts that may be mutually exclusive. This reflects the underlying conflicts and desires present in the unconscious mind, showcasing how dreams can serve as a battleground for competing thoughts and feelings.

POSITION 6,177 of 6,391
================================================================================

ID: FREUD-3129
Collection: EXTRACTED
Title: Preconscious Thought Dynamics
Work: Complete Works Part 5
Year: N/A
Domain: DREAM_THEORY

Text Evidence:
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Freud posits that trains of thought can exist in a preconscious state, where they are rational yet neglected or suppressed. These thoughts can continue to develop without conscious attention until they gain enough intensity to attract awareness. This process illustrates how thoughts can operate outside of conscious scrutiny, influenced by cathectic energy and unconscious wishes.

================================================================================
POSITION 6,178 of 6,391
================================================================================

ID: FREUD-3130
Collection: EXTRACTED
Title: Role of Cathexis in Thought
Work: Complete Works Part 5
Year: N/A
Domain: PSYCHOPATHOLOGY

Text Evidence:
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Freud describes cathexis as the investment of psychic energy in thoughts. When attention is withdrawn from a thought, it can either be neglected or suppressed. In both cases, the thought can persist in the preconscious, potentially connecting with unconscious wishes and gaining renewed energy, which may lead to its emergence into consciousness.

================================================================================
POSITION 6,179 of 6,391
================================================================================

ID: FREUD-3131
Collection: EXTRACTED
Title: Consciousness and Thought Suppression
Work: Complete Works Part 5
Year: N/A
Domain: METAPSYCHOLOGY

Text Evidence:
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Freud argues that consciousness plays a crucial role in determining which thoughts receive attention and cathexis. When a thought is deemed unworthy or incorrect, it may be suppressed, yet it can still persist in the preconscious, influenced by unconscious desires. This highlights the complex interplay between conscious judgment and unconscious processes.

================================================================================
POSITION 6,180 of 6,391
================================================================================

ID: FREUD-3132
Collection: EXTRACTED
Title: Associative Paths of Thought
Work: Complete Works Part 5
Year: N/A
Domain: DREAM_THEORY

Text Evidence:
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Freud suggests that thoughts follow associative paths, where a purposive idea can lead to the displacement of cathectic energy. If a thought is neglected, it may still resonate within the network of ideas, potentially connecting with unconscious wishes and leading to dream formation or other manifestations.

================================================================================
POSITION 6,181 of 6,391
================================================================================

ID: FREUD-3133
Collection: EXTRACTED
Title: Hypercathexis and Conscious Attention
Work: Complete Works Part 5
Year: N/A
Domain: CLINICAL_THEORY

Text Evidence:
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Freud introduces the concept of hypercathexis, where a train of thought, once neglected, can attract conscious attention and receive an intensified investment of psychic energy. This process underscores the dynamic nature of thought and the potential for repressed ideas to resurface under certain conditions.

================================================================================
POSITION 6,182 of 6,391
================================================================================

ID: FREUD-3134
Collection: EXTRACTED
Title: Inhibition of Excitation and Repression
Work: Complete Works Part 5
Year: N/A
Domain: PSYCHOPATHOLOGY

Text Evidence:
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
The avoidance of the memory, which is no more than a repetition of the previous flight from the perception, is also facilitated by the fact that the memory, unlike the perception, does not possess enough quality to excite consciousness and thus to attract fresh cathexis to itself. This effortless and regular avoidance by the psychical process of the memory of anything that had once been distressing affords us the prototype and first example of psychical repression.

================================================================================
POSITION 6,183 of 6,391
================================================================================

ID: FREUD-3135
Collection: EXTRACTED
Title: Pleasure Principle vs. Reality Principle
Work: Complete Works Part 5
Year: N/A
Domain: METAPSYCHOLOGY

Text Evidence:
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
The first -system is totally incapable of bringing anything disagreeable into the context of its thought. It is unable to do anything but wish. If things remained at that point, the thought-activity of the second system would be obstructed, since it requires free access to all the memories laid down by experience.

================================================================================
POSITION 6,184 of 6,391

ID: FREUD-3136
Collection: EXTRACTED
Title: Role of External Stimuli in Behavior
Work: Complete Works Part 5
Year: N/A
Domain: CLINICAL_THEORY

Text Evidence:
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Let us suppose that the primitive apparatus is impinged upon by a perceptual stimulus which is a source of painful excitation. Unco-ordinated motor manifestations will follow until one of them withdraws the apparatus from the perception and at the same time from the pain.

POSITION 6,209 of 6,391
================================================================================

ID: FREUD-3534
Collection: EXTRACTED
Title: Psychoanalysis vs. Hypnosis
Work: Complete Works Part 7
Year: N/A
Domain: TECHNIQUE

Text Evidence:
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Freud argues that the technique of psycho-analysis is superior to hypnosis because it does not merely evade resistance but seeks to understand the underlying psychical forces. Hypnosis may yield only transitory success and incomplete information, whereas psychoanalysis aims to make the unconscious accessible to consciousness by overcoming resistances.

================================================================================
POSITION 6,210 of 6,391
================================================================================

ID: FREUD-3535
Collection: EXTRACTED
Title: Goal of Psychoanalytic Treatment
Work: Complete Works Part 7
Year: N/A
Domain: CLINICAL_THEORY

Text Evidence:
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
The primary task of psychoanalytic treatment is to remove amnesias and undo repressions, thereby making the unconscious accessible to consciousness. This process aims to restore the patient's ability to lead an active life and enjoy it, highlighting that health and sickness are not fundamentally different but exist on a continuum.

================================================================================
POSITION 6,211 of 6,391
================================================================================

ID: FREUD-3536
Collection: EXTRACTED
Title: Resistance in Psychoanalysis
Work: Complete Works Part 7
Year: N/A
Domain: PSYCHOPATHOLOGY

Text Evidence:
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Freud emphasizes that resistance is a crucial element in psychoanalysis, as it obstructs the physician's insight into the patient's mental processes. The psychoanalytic method seeks to confront and understand these resistances rather than avoid them, which is a limitation of hypnosis.

================================================================================
POSITION 6,212 of 6,391

Collection: EXTRACTED
Title: Nature of Mental Health
Work: Complete Works Part 7
Year: N/A
Domain: DEVELOPMENTAL_THEORY

Text Evidence:
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Freud posits that mental health and illness are not distinct entities but rather exist on a quantitative spectrum. The goal of treatment is not to achieve an ideal state of health but to facilitate significant improvement in the patient's mental condition, even if symptoms persist.

================================================================================

Work: Complete Works Part 7
Year: N/A
Domain: CLINICAL_THEORY

Text Evidence:
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Freud expresses skepticism about the effectiveness of suggestion in hypnosis, noting that it often fails to produce lasting cures. He argues that the suggestions applied tend to crumble, leading to a recurrence of the illness or its manifestations, indicating that deeper mental forces are at play that must be understood for effective treatment.

He highlights the necessity of understanding the intricacies of mental treatment, comparing it to the requirement of knowledge in histological techniques for examining physical ailments.

POSITION 6,227 of 6,391

Text Evidence:
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Freud discusses how individuals predisposed to hysteria may experience a dissociation of mental processes, leading to a separation between conscious awareness and unconscious experiences. This dissociation results in the manifestation of symptoms that reflect the underlying psychical state rather than being caused by autosuggestion.

Text Evidence:
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------

This perspective contrasts with static views that attribute dissociation to inherent incapacity, suggesting instead that it is a result of psychological conflict.

Work: Complete Works Part 12
Year: N/A

Text Evidence:

The first task confronting psycho-analysis was to explain the neuroses; it used the two facts of resistance and transference as starting-points, and, taking into consideration the third fact of amnesia, accounted for them with its theories of repression, of the sexual motive forces in neurosis and of the unconscious.

Domain: DEVELOPMENTAL_THEORY

Text Evidence:
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
It shows the disguise under which the factor of infantilism, which is so strongly emphasized by psycho-analysis, re-appears in 'Individual Psychology'.

Text Evidence:

Careful dissection of a neurosis in early childhood puts an end to all misapprehensions about the aetiology of the neuroses and to all doubts about the part played by the sexual instincts in them.

POSITION 6,291 of 6,391

ID: FREUD-4729
Collection: EXTRACTED
Title: Forgetting as Defense Mechanism
Work: Complete Works Part 13
Year: N/A
Domain: PSYCHOPATHOLOGY

Text Evidence:
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
The forgetting of impressions and experiences demonstrates the operation of the purpose of keeping disagreeable things out of memory. Disagreeable impressions are easily forgotten, indicating a mental defense against unpleasurable impulses. This suggests that forgetting serves a protective function in our psychological life.

================================================================================

ID: FREUD-4730
Collection: EXTRACTED
Title: Contradictions in Mental Life
Work: Complete Works Part 13
Year: N/A
Domain: METAPSYCHOLOGY

Text Evidence:
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Mental life is the arena for mutually opposing purposes, consisting of contradictions and pairs of contraries. The existence of a particular purpose does not negate the existence of an opposite one; both can coexist and influence our mental processes.

================================================================================
POSITION 6,293 of 6,391
================================================================================

ID: FREUD-4731
Collection: EXTRACTED
Title: Purpose Behind Memory Loss
Work: Complete Works Part 13
Year: N/A
Domain: CLINICAL_THEORY

Text Evidence:
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
All cases of losing or mislaying items share a commonality: there was a wish to lose something. The basis and aim of that wish can differ, indicating that memory loss can serve multiple psychological purposes, such as emotional distancing or the desire to forget unpleasant associations.

================================================================================
POSITION 6,294 of 6,391
================================================================================

ID: FREUD-4732
Collection: EXTRACTED
Title: Impact of Early Experiences
Work: Complete Works Part 13
Year: N/A
Domain: DEVELOPMENTAL_THEORY

Text Evidence:
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Experiences from our earliest childhood years can be deeply impressionable yet are often forgotten. This suggests that the mechanisms of forgetting are complex and not solely based on the unpleasantness of the memories, but also on their emotional significance and the psychological context.

================================================================================

Title: Social Implications of Memory
Work: Complete Works Part 13
Year: N/A
Domain: CULTURAL_THEORY

Text Evidence:
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
In social life, it has been observed that unwanted and illegitimate children are often more frail than those conceived legitimately. This observation highlights the broader implications of psychological processes, such as memory and forgetting, on social and familial dynamics.

All the peoples of antiquity attached great significance to dreams and thought they could be used for practical purposes. They deduced signs for the future from them and searched in them for auguries.

Text Evidence:

According to an old analogy, the contents of a dream are like the sounds produced when 'the ten fingers of a man who knows nothing of music wander over the keys of a piano.'

Work: Complete Works Part 13
Year: N/A
Domain: DREAM_THEORY

Text Evidence:
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Freud posits that dreams are reactions to stimuli that disturb sleep. He cites experimental evidence showing that external stimuli during sleep can manifest in dreams, illustrating how sensory experiences influence dream content.

Work: Complete Works Part 13
Year: N/A
Domain: DREAM_THEORY

Text Evidence:
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Freud notes that personal observations can confirm the findings of experimental psychology regarding dreams. He references the work of Maury and others who experienced dreams influenced by specific stimuli, reinforcing the connection between waking experiences and dream content.

Title: Experimental Evidence of Dream Content
Work: Complete Works Part 13
Year: N/A
Domain: DREAM_THEORY

Text Evidence:
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Freud discusses various experiments where individuals reported dreams triggered by specific stimuli, such as scents or sounds. These examples demonstrate how external factors can shape the narrative and imagery of dreams, supporting the idea that dreams are not purely random.

Title: Influence of Alarm Clocks on Dreams
Work: Complete Works Part 13
Year: N/A
Domain: DREAM_THEORY

Text Evidence:
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Freud provides examples of dreams that were directly influenced by the ringing of alarm clocks, showing how a simple external sound can lead to complex dream scenarios. This illustrates the interplay between external stimuli and the dream state.

================================================================================
POSITION 6,305 of 6,391
================================================================================

ID: FREUD-4929
Collection: EXTRACTED
Title: Ego's Unreliability in Understanding the Unconscious
Work: Complete Works Part 14
Year: N/A
Domain: PSYCHOPATHOLOGY

Text Evidence:
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
The ego is not a trustworthy or impartial agency. It disavows the unconscious and represses its demands, particularly those related to sexuality. Therefore, we cannot rely on the ego's assertions to accurately represent the unconscious or the true nature of neurotic symptoms.

================================================================================

Collection: EXTRACTED
Title: Repression and Its Consequences
Work: Complete Works Part 14
Year: N/A
Domain: PSYCHOPATHOLOGY

Text Evidence:
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
The concept of repression warns us against trusting the ego's perspective in understanding neuroses. The ego's view is often skewed, leading to misconceptions about the origins and nature of symptoms, which are deeply rooted in repressed unconscious desires.

Work: Complete Works Part 14

Domain: SEXUALITY_THEORY

Text Evidence:
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
The most prominent elements in what is repressed are the repudiated demands of sexuality. The extent and importance of these demands cannot be accurately gauged from the egos conceptions, highlighting the critical role of sexuality in the formation of neuroses.

Text Evidence:
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Narcissistic neuroses illustrate a more intensive role of the ego in symptom formation. Future investigations into these disorders will provide a clearer understanding of the ego's involvement in the onset of neuroses, emphasizing the complexity of its functions.

Text Evidence:
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
The ego often exhibits passivity, which it attempts to disguise. This passivity is evident in obsessional neuroses, where the ego confronts alien forces that it struggles to manage, indicating that the ego's role is not solely active or creative.

Title: Ego's Role in Neurosis
Work: Complete Works Part 14
Year: N/A
Domain: PSYCHOPATHOLOGY

Text Evidence:
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
A person only falls ill of a neurosis if his ego has lost the capacity to allocate his libido in some way. The stronger is his ego, the easier will it be for it to carry out that task.

The sexual function is not a purely psychical thing any more than it is a purely somatic one. It influences bodily and mental life alike.

Text Evidence:
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
The symptoms of the actual neuroses... have no sense, no psychical meaning. They are not only manifested predominantly in the body... but they are also themselves entirely somatic processes.

Work: Complete Works Part 14
Year: N/A
Domain: PSYCHOPATHOLOGY

Text Evidence:
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Any weakening of his ego from whatever cause must have the same effect as an excessive increase in the claims of the libido and will thus make it possible for him to fall ill of a neurosis.

================================================================================
POSITION 6,315 of 6,391
================================================================================

ID: FREUD-4939
Collection: EXTRACTED
Title: Anxiety as Non-Essential Response
Work: Complete Works Part 14
Year: N/A
Domain: PSYCHOPATHOLOGY

Text Evidence:
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
The generation of anxiety is never an expedient thing. It may perhaps help us to see more clearly if we dissect the situation of anxiety more carefully. The first thing about it is preparedness for the danger, which manifests itself in increased sensory attention and motor tension. This expectant preparedness can be unhesitatingly recognized as an advantage; indeed, its absence may be made responsible for serious consequences.

================================================================================
POSITION 6,316 of 6,391
================================================================================

ID: FREUD-4940
Collection: EXTRACTED
Title: Knowledge Alters Perception of Danger
Work: Complete Works Part 14
Year: N/A
Domain: CULTURAL_THEORY

Text Evidence:
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
We can quite understand how a savage is afraid of a cannon and frightened by an eclipse of the sun, while a white man, who knows how to handle the instrument and can foretell the eclipse, remains without anxiety in these circumstances. On other occasions it is actually superior knowledge that promotes anxiety, because it makes an early recognition of the danger possible.

================================================================================
POSITION 6,317 of 6,391
================================================================================

ID: FREUD-4941
Collection: EXTRACTED
Title: Anxiety Paralyzes Action
Work: Complete Works Part 14
Year: N/A
Domain: PSYCHOPATHOLOGY

Text Evidence:
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
If the anxiety is excessively great it proves in the highest degree inexpedient; it paralyses all action, including even flight. Usually the reaction to danger consists in a mixture of the affect of anxiety and defensive action.

================================================================================
POSITION 6,318 of 6,391
================================================================================

ID: FREUD-4942
Collection: EXTRACTED
Title: Preparedness vs. Anxiety
Work: Complete Works Part 14
Year: N/A
Domain: TECHNIQUE

Text Evidence:
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Accordingly, the preparedness for anxiety seems to me to be the expedient element in what we call anxiety, and the generation of anxiety the inexpedient one. The more the generation of anxiety is limited to a mere abortive beginning - to a signal - the more will the preparedness for anxiety transform itself without disturbance into action.

================================================================================
POSITION 6,319 of 6,391
================================================================================

ID: FREUD-5129
Collection: EXTRACTED
Title: The Uncanny and the Double
Work: Complete Works Part 15
Year: N/A
Domain: CULTURAL_THEORY

Text Evidence:
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
The theme of the double has been very thoroughly treated by Otto Rank. It represents an insurance against the destruction of the ego, an energetic denial of the power of death. Originally, the double was a means of preserving the self, but it later becomes an uncanny harbinger of death, reflecting the evolution of the idea from a protective symbol to a source of anxiety.

================================================================================

================================================================================

ID: FREUD-5130
Collection: EXTRACTED
Title: Infantile Sources of Uncanny Themes
Work: Complete Works Part 15
Year: N/A
Domain: DEVELOPMENTAL_THEORY

Text Evidence:
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
We must content ourselves with selecting those themes of uncanniness which are most prominent and seeing whether they too can fairly be traced back to infantile sources. This suggests that the roots of our fears and uncanny experiences are deeply embedded in early childhood development.

================================================================================

Domain: DREAM_THEORY

Text Evidence:
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
The language of dreams is fond of representing castration by a doubling or multiplication of a genital symbol. This indicates that the concept of doubling is intricately linked to fundamental anxieties surrounding identity and sexuality.

Such ideas have sprung from the soil of unbounded self-love, from the primary narcissism which dominates the mind of the child and of primitive man. This highlights the connection between narcissism and the development of the self-concept through the notion of the double.

POSITION 6,323 of 6,391

Collection: EXTRACTED
Title: Evolution of the Idea of the Double
Work: Complete Works Part 15
Year: N/A
Domain: METAPSYCHOLOGY

Text Evidence:
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
The idea of the double does not necessarily remain static; it evolves from being a protective symbol against death to becoming a source of uncanny dread. This evolution reflects deeper psychological transformations in human consciousness.

================================================================================
POSITION 6,324 of 6,391
================================================================================

ID: FREUD-5134
Collection: EXTRACTED
Title: Omnipotence of Thoughts
Work: Complete Works Part 15
Year: N/A
Domain: METAPSYCHOLOGY

Text Evidence:
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Freud introduces the concept of the 'omnipotence of thoughts', suggesting that individuals may believe their thoughts can influence reality. This belief is rooted in an animistic worldview where mental processes are overvalued, leading to a sense of magical thinking. Such beliefs can manifest in feelings of anxiety and the uncanny when repressed thoughts resurface.

================================================================================
POSITION 6,325 of 6,391
================================================================================

ID: FREUD-5135
Collection: EXTRACTED
Title: The Uncanny and Repression
Work: Complete Works Part 15
Year: N/A
Domain: PSYCHOPATHOLOGY

Text Evidence:
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Freud posits that the uncanny arises from repressed emotions or thoughts that resurface, creating feelings of fear or discomfort. This phenomenon suggests that what is perceived as alien or frightening is often familiar, having been pushed out of conscious awareness due to repression. The uncanny thus reflects a return of the repressed.

================================================================================
POSITION 6,326 of 6,391
================================================================================

ID: FREUD-5136
Collection: EXTRACTED
Title: Animistic Mental Activity
Work: Complete Works Part 15
Year: N/A
Domain: DEVELOPMENTAL_THEORY

Text Evidence:
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Freud argues that all individuals pass through a developmental phase characterized by animistic thinking, where the world is seen as populated by spirits and magical powers. This stage leaves residues in the psyche, which can later manifest as feelings of the uncanny when triggered by certain stimuli.

================================================================================
POSITION 6,327 of 6,391
================================================================================

ID: FREUD-5137
Collection: EXTRACTED
Title: Fear and Anxiety Transformation
Work: Complete Works Part 15
Year: N/A
Domain: CLINICAL_THEORY

Text Evidence:
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Freud claims that any emotional impulse, when repressed, transforms into anxiety. This transformation indicates that the uncanny can be linked to repressed fears, suggesting that the frightening elements in our lives often originate from unresolved emotional conflicts.

================================================================================

Work: Complete Works Part 15

Domain: CULTURAL_THEORY

Text Evidence:
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Freud suggests that traces of animistic beliefs persist in contemporary culture, influencing how individuals perceive the uncanny. This cultural residue reflects a collective psychological heritage that shapes our understanding of fear and the supernatural.

Domain: PSYCHOPATHOLOGY

Text Evidence:
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
The uncanny proceeds from something familiar that has been repressed. This suggests that feelings of uncanniness arise when familiar elements resurface in a distorted or unexpected manner, triggering a sense of discomfort or fear.

Text Evidence:
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
We must be prepared to admit that there are other elements besides those which we have so far laid down as determining the production of uncanny feelings, including intellectual uncertainty, which plays a significant role in our experience of fear.

Work: Complete Works Part 15
Year: N/A
Domain: CULTURAL_THEORY

Text Evidence:
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
We should differentiate between the uncanny that we actually experience and the uncanny that we merely picture or read about. The experienced uncanny is more simply conditioned and fits better with the notion of repressed familiarity.

Text Evidence:
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
The feeling of uncanniness arises when we encounter situations that seem to confirm old, discarded beliefs about the omnipotence of thoughts and the return of the dead, leading to a clash between past beliefs and current understanding.

Domain: DEVELOPMENTAL_THEORY

Text Evidence:
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
The uncanny effect of silence, darkness, and solitude points to the part played by danger in the genesis of what is uncanny, particularly in children, where these factors often trigger expressions of fear.

================================================================================
POSITION 6,334 of 6,391
================================================================================

ID: FREUD-5329
Collection: EXTRACTED
Title: Consciousness vs. Unconsciousness
Work: Complete Works Part 16
Year: N/A
Domain: METAPSYCHOLOGY

Text Evidence:
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
The division of the psychical into what is conscious and what is unconscious is the fundamental premiss of psycho-analysis; and it alone makes it possible for psycho-analysis to understand the pathological processes in mental life. Psycho-analysis cannot situate the essence of the psychical in consciousness, but must regard consciousness as a quality of the psychical, which may be present in addition to other qualities or may be absent.

================================================================================
POSITION 6,335 of 6,391
================================================================================

ID: FREUD-5330
Collection: EXTRACTED
Title: Transitory Nature of Consciousness
Work: Complete Works Part 16
Year: N/A
Domain: PSYCHOPATHOLOGY

Text Evidence:
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Experience shows that a psychical element (for instance, an idea) is not as a rule conscious for a protracted length of time. A state of consciousness is characteristically very transitory; an idea that is conscious now is no longer so a moment later, although it can become so again under certain conditions.

================================================================================
POSITION 6,336 of 6,391
================================================================================

ID: FREUD-5331
Collection: EXTRACTED
Title: Latent Ideas and the Unconscious
Work: Complete Works Part 16
Year: N/A
Domain: DREAM_THEORY

Text Evidence:
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
We can say that an idea was latent, meaning it was capable of becoming conscious at any time. If we say that it was unconscious, we are also giving a correct description of it. Here 'unconscious' coincides with 'latent and capable of becoming conscious'.

================================================================================
POSITION 6,337 of 6,391
================================================================================

ID: FREUD-5332
Collection: EXTRACTED
Title: Philosophical Resistance to the Unconscious
Work: Complete Works Part 16
Year: N/A
Domain: CULTURAL_THEORY

Text Evidence:
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
To most people educated in philosophy, the idea of anything psychical which is not also conscious is inconceivable and seems absurd. This resistance arises because they have never studied relevant phenomena like hypnosis and dreams, which necessitate the view of the unconscious.

================================================================================

Year: N/A
Domain: METAPSYCHOLOGY

Text Evidence:
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
The question, How does a thing become conscious? would thus be more advantageously stated: How does a thing become preconscious? And the answer would be: Through becoming connected with the word-presentations corresponding to it.

================================================================================

Domain: PSYCHOPATHOLOGY

Text Evidence:
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Only something which has once been a Cs. perception can become conscious, and that anything arising from within (apart from feelings) that seeks to become conscious must try to transform itself into external perceptions: this becomes possible by means of memory-traces.

When a memory is revived the cathexis remains in the mnemic system, whereas a hallucination... can arise when the cathexis does not merely spread over from the memory-trace on to the Pcpt. element, but passes over to it entirely.

In our analyses we discover that there are people in whom the faculties of self-criticism and conscience are unconscious and unconsciously produce effects of the greatest importance; in a great number of neuroses, an unconscious sense of guilt plays a decisive economic part and puts the most powerful obstacles in the way of recovery.

Text Evidence:
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
The ego is not merely the part of the id modified by the influence of the perceptual system; it includes a differentiation known as the 'ego ideal' or 'super-ego', which is less firmly connected with consciousness and plays a significant role in shaping the character.

Instances of coming into consciousness during sleep show that individuals may find solutions to problems upon waking, indicating that the unconscious mind can process and resolve complex issues.

Text Evidence:
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
The process of substitution, where an object-cathexis is replaced by an identification, is common and essential in determining the form taken by the ego and contributes to the development of an individual's character.

================================================================================
POSITION 6,347 of 6,391
================================================================================

ID: FREUD-5529
Collection: EXTRACTED
Title: Anxiety as Reproduced Affective State
Work: Complete Works Part 17
Year: N/A
Domain: PSYCHOPATHOLOGY

Text Evidence:
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Anxiety is not newly created in repression; it is reproduced as an affective state in accordance with an already existing mnemic image. Affective states have become incorporated in the mind as precipitates of primaeval traumatic experiences, and when a similar situation occurs they are revived like mnemic symbols.

================================================================================
POSITION 6,348 of 6,391
================================================================================

Collection: EXTRACTED
Title: Birth as First Experience of Anxiety
Work: Complete Works Part 17
Year: N/A
Domain: DEVELOPMENTAL_THEORY

Text Evidence:
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
In man and the higher animals it would seem that the act of birth, as the individuals first experience of anxiety, has given the affect of anxiety certain characteristic forms of expression. However, we must not lay undue stress on this connection.

================================================================================
POSITION 6,349 of 6,391
================================================================================

ID: FREUD-5531
Collection: EXTRACTED
Title: Repression and Super-Ego Dynamics
Work: Complete Works Part 17
Year: N/A
Domain: CLINICAL_THEORY

Text Evidence:
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Far too little is known as yet about the background and preliminary stages of repression. There is a danger of over-estimating the part played in repression by the super-ego. The earliest outbreaks of anxiety occur before the super-ego has become differentiated.

================================================================================
POSITION 6,350 of 6,391
================================================================================

ID: FREUD-5532
Collection: EXTRACTED
Title: Primal Repression and After-Pressure
Work: Complete Works Part 17
Year: N/A
Domain: PSYCHOPATHOLOGY

Text Evidence:
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Most of the repressions with which we have to deal in our therapeutic work are cases of after-pressure. They presuppose the operation of earlier, primal repressions which exert an attraction on the more recent situation.

================================================================================

Text Evidence:
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
It is highly probable that the immediate precipitating causes of primal repressions are quantitative factors such as an excessive degree of excitation and the breaking through of the protective shield against stimuli.

================================================================================
POSITION 6,352 of 6,391
================================================================================

ID: FREUD-5534
Collection: EXTRACTED
Title: Symptoms as Repressed Impulses
Work: Complete Works Part 17
Year: N/A
Domain: PSYCHOPATHOLOGY

Text Evidence:
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
The symptom, being the true substitute for and derivative of the repressed impulse, carries on the role of the latter; it continually renews its demands for satisfaction and thus obliges the ego in its turn to give the signal of unpleasure and put itself in a posture of defence.

Year: N/A
Domain: CLINICAL_THEORY

Text Evidence:
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
In a concrete case of neurotic illness the state of affairs is much more complex than one would suppose so long as one was dealing with abstractions. It takes a little time to find ones bearings and to decide which the repressed impulse is, what substitutive symptom it has found and where the motive for repression lies.

POSITION 6,357 of 6,391
================================================================================

ID: FREUD-5539
Collection: EXTRACTED
Title: Repression and Phobia Formation
Work: Complete Works Part 17
Year: N/A
Domain: PSYCHOPATHOLOGY

Text Evidence:
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
The formation of phobias is closely linked to the process of repression, which can affect both aggressive and tender impulses within the Oedipus complex. In 'Little Hans,' repression targeted his feelings towards both parents, leading to the development of a phobia. This illustrates how repressed emotions can manifest as symptoms, complicating the understanding of neuroses.

================================================================================
POSITION 6,358 of 6,391
================================================================================

ID: FREUD-5540
Collection: EXTRACTED
Title: Oedipus Complex Dynamics
Work: Complete Works Part 17
Year: N/A
Domain: DEVELOPMENTAL_THEORY

Text Evidence:
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
The Oedipus complex involves both hostile and affectionate feelings towards parents. In the case of 'Little Hans,' his phobia was a result of repressed aggressive impulses towards his father and affectionate feelings towards his mother. This complex interplay of emotions is crucial in understanding childhood neuroses and their manifestations.

================================================================================

Work: Complete Works Part 17
Year: N/A
Domain: CLINICAL_THEORY

Text Evidence:
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Despite similarities in the outcomes of phobia formation, individual cases like 'Little Hans' and the Russian patient reveal significant differences in the underlying dynamics of repression. Each case illustrates how personal history and emotional development can lead to distinct manifestations of neuroses, emphasizing the complexity of psychological analysis.

Text Evidence:
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
In both 'Little Hans' and the Russian patient, the fear of impending castration emerged as a common motive force behind repression. This fear influenced their emotional development and the formation of phobias, highlighting the central role of this anxiety in psychoanalytic theory.

The process of civilization and the developmental process of individuals are very similar in nature, both aiming at integrationone of individuals into a community and the other of a community from individuals. This challenges the notion of fetishism as a symptom of an underlying ailment.

Freud discusses the complex interplay between the disavowal and acknowledgment of castration, particularly in the context of fetishism. This reflects a deeper psychological struggle regarding gender and power dynamics.

Title: Fetishism as Psychological Projection
Work: Complete Works Part 18
Year: N/A
Domain: SEXUALITY_THEORY

Text Evidence:
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Freud posits that the normal prototype of fetishes is a man's penis, while inferior organs are represented by a woman's clitoris. This indicates that fetishism is not merely a sexual phenomenon but a projection of deeper psychological conflicts regarding sexuality and identity.

================================================================================
POSITION 6,372 of 6,391
================================================================================

ID: FREUD-5739
Collection: EXTRACTED
Title: Humor as Economic Pleasure
Work: Complete Works Part 18
Year: N/A
Domain: CLINICAL_THEORY

Text Evidence:
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
In his analysis of humor, Freud argues that the pleasure derived from humor arises from an economy of emotional expenditure. He identifies two modes of humor: one where the subject creates humor for themselves and another where an observer finds humor in the actions of others, suggesting a complex interplay between self and social dynamics in humor.

Title: Cultural Fetishism and Submission
Work: Complete Works Part 18
Year: N/A
Domain: CULTURAL_THEORY

Text Evidence:
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Freud draws parallels between individual fetishism and cultural practices, such as the Chinese custom of foot binding. He suggests that such practices reflect a societal acknowledgment of castration and submission, where the male gaze fetishizes the mutilated female body as a form of reverence.

Work: Complete Works Part 19
Year: N/A
Domain: DREAM_THEORY

Text Evidence:

I was faced by the task of interpreting dreams in a way that could stand up against scientific criticism. People dream about the things that have engaged their minds during the waking day. Dreams were only a substitute for a rational process of thought and could be interpreted.

The expectation that fate will treat us poorly is often a projection of our own conscience. This reflects how internal moral judgments can shape our perceptions of external events, influencing our emotional responses to both success and failure.

Freud reflects on his personal experiences with anti-Semitism, noting how it has affected his life and work. Title: Persecution and Sympathy
Work: Complete Works Part 20
Year: N/A
Domain: CULTURAL_THEORY

Text Evidence:
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Freud questions whether the current persecution of Jews should evoke a wave of sympathy from non-Jewish individuals. He suggests that rather than remaining silent, there should be a collective acknowledgment of suffering and a call for empathy in the face of injustice.

POSITION 6,391 of 6,391

Collection: EXTRACTED
Title: Personal Involvement in Discourse
Work: Complete Works Part 20
Year: N/A
Domain: CULTURAL_THEORY

Text Evidence:
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Freud argues for the importance of including voices that are personally affected by issues like anti-Semitism in public discourse. He challenges the notion that non-Jewish perspectives should dominate discussions about Jewish suffering, advocating for the representation of those directly impacted.
